She seemed to be dedicated to her “second job” of documenting the world around her. “She was a true artist who followed her dreams,” said Rydzon. “Nothing stopped her.”

Maier’s work is pure art; she did not create it for commercial purposes. Her photographs often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects. “What is fascinating about Vivian is the number of interesting pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style or borrowed ideas from others.

Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever sort through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof began taking his own pictures. “As I grew as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It was the people, the street scenes, and the overall composition,” he said. “There was so much more to her work than I initially thought, and I realized I was holding something more important than I ever imagined. Now, our goal is to make her name known and ensure Vivian Maier is recognized in history.”

When a novel is called ambitious, it often suggests that it has not fully succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK during a time when her book was very successful, and she was at the center of a lot of attention. Despite being in her twenties, she appeared calm. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. 

She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass, and the official asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s, where a series of crimes have occurred, leading a council of 12 men to come together to solve them. The plot becomes very complex. Catton intended to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past allowed for more complications and misunderstandings for her characters.

At over 800 pages, the book is “big by necessity” because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a fair chance to shine. When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she responded by saying that coming from a small country makes everyone feel a part of her success. She received a lot of support from people back home, including “back pats from other people’s grandmas.” However, she expressed frustration when people assume her book is not a serious philosophical work.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in a spiral shape, where each part is half the length of the previous one, making the story speed up as it progresses. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said she aimed to create a book with structural patterns that might not be important, but if readers cared, they could find them.

Despite its unique structure, The Luminaries remains an exciting murder mystery with a captivating plot. Interestingly, Catton did not plan the story in advance. She would write herself into difficult situations and then see how creatively she could resolve them. One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers. 

We also discussed her love for television dramas, noting how The Luminaries uses cliff-hangers, multiple viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would be interested in screenwriting, and she replied, “That could be pretty cool.” Her enthusiasm was clear, and she laughed softly as she spoke about her writing and New Zealand. 

She mentioned that being in Britain changes her perspective and helps her understand why writers often leave New Zealand for more populated areas. However, for now, New Zealand will remain her home, and I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

As a child, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either building things in his dad’s garage or playing the guitar. For the last forty years, he has made a living by handcrafting steel-string acoustic guitars. He expresses his fascination with the guitar, wondering how two pieces of wood can create such beautiful sounds and how different types of wood can change the sound. Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar at eleven and wanted to learn the bass guitar at sixteen. Instead of saving money for one, he decided to build it himself. He studied how different shapes and woods affect sound and learned how to put them together.

Before making the bass guitar, Jonny and his brothers had already built model boats and planes, so he was familiar with the process. His father taught them how to use tools like saws and chisels. Jonny had also customized and repaired instruments for his friends. Although his bass guitar turned out well, he hadn’t thought about a career in guitar-making at that time. He was also interested in painting and sculpture, so after finishing school, he chose to study architecture at university, believing it combined design and a promising career.

However, halfway through the architecture course, he dropped out, feeling it didn’t suit his individualistic nature. He realized that guitar-making was a form of sculpture that involved creating sound, and he thought it might be a more practical career than pure art since it involved making useful items. Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he worked part-time cleaning windows to support himself. Initially, he sold his guitars for just the cost of materials, but as he gained a reputation as a skilled guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, nearly forty years later, he describes his work as “still scratching a living,” as he can only make about ten guitars a year, limiting his income.

In the early years, Jonny focused on getting known. He attended music festivals on weekends, encouraging musicians to try his guitars and spread the word. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, as he wasn’t naturally inclined to think about such matters. Jonny believes that it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. When he started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were valuable, even though the UK has always had good instrument-making courses and skilled craftsmen. Now, however, UK-made guitars have gained the recognition they deserve.

Jonny thinks that valuable skills can be learned in classrooms, and he encourages new instrument-makers to take available courses. However, he also believes that there is no substitute for learning through experience. He advises looking at other instruments to see what works and what doesn’t. For example, if the back of a guitar is too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. He feels that being self-taught allows for a broader understanding, while learning from someone else may limit you to just one method.

Any discussion about English conversation usually starts with the weather. Following this tradition, I will mention the well-known remark by the 18th-century writer Dr. Johnson, who said, "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This statement is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many commentators stop here or struggle to explain why the English seem so focused on the weather. They often make a mistake by thinking that when we talk about the weather, we are genuinely interested in it. 

For instance, the American writer Bill Bryson points out that English weather is not particularly interesting. He notes that in England, we don’t experience extreme weather events like tornadoes or monsoons, which are common in other places. Therefore, he finds it hard to understand why the English are so preoccupied with it. In response, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman argues that Bryson misses the point. He believes that the English interest in the weather is not about strong feelings; rather, it is about its unpredictability. Living on the edge of an ocean means that the weather is always changing, and you can never be completely sure what to expect.

From my research, I believe both Bryson and Paxman overlook the real reason for our weather conversations. These discussions are not truly about the weather; they serve as a social tool for English people to connect with one another. Phrases like "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" are not genuine inquiries about the weather. Instead, they are standard greetings or conversation starters that help break the ice. 

In a way, English weather talk is similar to "social grooming" seen in monkeys and apes, who spend time grooming each other to bond socially. There are specific situations where weather talk is appropriate. Some writers claim that the English talk about the weather all the time, but this is not accurate. In reality, there are three main contexts for weather talk: as a simple greeting, as a way to start a conversation about other topics, or as a fallback topic when conversations stall and there is an awkward silence. 

This frequent use of weather talk can give outsiders the impression that English people discuss nothing else. An English conversation might begin with a weather-related greeting, move to more weather talk to ease into other subjects, and then return to weather talk when the conversation slows down. This pattern explains why many people, including some English commentators, believe that the English are obsessed with the weather.

Alice Leader stood in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an amazing engineering achievement it was for the Romans to build a structure that is 120 km long and 5 meters high around 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip, choosing it over more glamorous tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they were curious about why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not enough. Unable to find a suitable historical novel to provide context about life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself.

After retiring from teaching for 31 years, Alice began her new career as an author in 2001. Although she had a successful teaching career, she felt she was stepping into the unknown. She compared teaching to acting, saying it was physically demanding, while writing was exciting but less exhausting. Her former colleagues envied her because she still connected with children through her stories.

Alice aims to fill a gap in children's fiction. She noted that much of today’s adolescent fiction focuses on negative experiences, which, while well-written, often presents dark realities or total fantasy, like Harry Potter. Her books are different. She always tried to teach English and History together, using lessons about ancient Greece alongside the novel "Tale of Troy." She is motivated by her love for children and enjoys the moment when a child goes from boredom to interest and understanding. She sees her writing as an extension of her teaching.

Alice was inspired to write her first novel partly because she noticed a gap in the market, but also because her two sons were leaving home, creating an "empty nest." Additionally, her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course. Initially, Alice was hesitant, not wanting to spend her summer on a course she thought unnecessary. However, she had to submit her best piece of fiction to be accepted, which she only learned a few days before the course started. She quickly created a story about a Roman couple and their unborn child. After three hours and 30 pages, she submitted it and was accepted.

During the course, her classmates reviewed her work and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice's husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help was crucial in editing her novel. Alice believes they complement each other; he improves her writing by changing sentence structures and suggesting word changes, while her instinct is to add more scenes. This difference highlights the roles of a fiction writer and an editor.

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to participate in a special race. This race would have Jonny racing in a car on the roads, while Alistair would race on a mountain bike across the countryside. The race took place in the beautiful and rugged Yorkshire Dales in northern England, starting at Semerwater lake and ending at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters high.

As they prepared to start, Jonny expressed his excitement, saying he had never done anything like this before and was looking forward to the beautiful views from the car, especially since it was very cold outside. Alistair, dressed in full winter cycling gear, was also eager but joked that he might stop for tea because he was unsure if Jonny could drive well enough to win.

The race began, and Alistair quickly took off on his bike, heading straight up the hill. Jonny got into his car and started driving. However, just 15 seconds into his drive, he encountered a large tractor blocking the road. He complained to the cameraman about the delay, saying if Alistair won, it would be because of the farmer.

Once past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair faced challenges on the steep slope. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, which was a strange sight for the sheep watching him. After a tough climb, Alistair finally reached the top and began to pick up speed as he rode down the other side.

Meanwhile, Jonny was dealing with narrow roads and obstacles in the villages, which made it hard for him to drive quickly. He carefully navigated through a narrow corner and a stream on the road. Once he was clear of the last village, he sped towards the finish line.

Neither brother knew how close they were to each other. As Jonny accelerated down the final stretch, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. Just as he reached the finish line, he asked the crowd if Jonny had arrived yet. When they said no, he celebrated, thinking he had won.

A few moments later, Jonny's car pulled up, and he stepped out, looking disappointed. He congratulated Alistair, saying, "Well done," but admitted he was upset about losing.

The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass, toss it up to serve, and hit it, hearing only the echo of your own shots. The well-kept grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a peaceful atmosphere that separates you from the outside world. This quiet is beneficial for my game. The biggest challenge during a match is to focus only on the game and the current point. When a point ends, the silence is broken by applause, cheers, and people shouting your name. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t realize there are fifteen thousand people watching closely, or that millions are watching me play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final, the most important match of my life.

I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach since I was young, taught me that this is the biggest tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing my dream with friends that I would play there one day and win. However, before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice in the finals, once in 2006 and again in 2007. The loss in 2006 was not too hard; I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer won easily, but the defeat in 2007 was devastating. I knew I could have performed better; it was not my skills that let me down, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing is always painful, but it hurts more when you have a chance and fail to take it.

Toni, who is usually very tough and critical, surprised me by saying there was no reason to cry and that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand; I felt this might be my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career can be, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment is important, but some moments are more significant than others, and I had let a big opportunity slip away in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to comfort me, but he turned out to be right. Another chance came just a year later in 2008. I felt confident I had learned from my previous defeat; this time, my mindset would be strong. 

The night before the final, at dinner with family, friends, and team members, we avoided talking about the match. I didn’t explicitly tell them not to mention it, but they understood that I was already mentally preparing for the game. From that moment until the match started, that mental space was mine alone.

In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood.” This woman was Jane Goodall, and she would spend most of her life in Africa as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, Jane Goodall gained fame when Britain’s National Geographical Society published articles and made documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her popularity grew with her own writings, including award-winning children’s books and the 1971 bestseller *In the Shadow of Man*, which has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real accomplishments. Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on sentimental aspects and do not fully capture her work. 

People have portrayed her in various ways: as an adventurous girl, a privileged woman who wanted to live with wild animals, and a determined feminist in a male-dominated field. These portrayals can diminish her true contributions. Based on academic references to her research, the success of her students in biology, and the extensive data she collected over forty years, Jane Goodall should be recognized as a pioneering zoologist. More simply, she opened our eyes to the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees.

Before Goodall's work, wild chimpanzees were seen as dangerous, and many misconceptions existed about them. For example, no one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools, and we did not understand that they share emotions similar to humans or have complex social structures. Goodall discovered that chimpanzee communities in Africa have unique cultural traditions. Her book, *The Chimpanzees of Gombe* (1986), is the most authoritative work on this subject and serves as the first encyclopedia for chimpanzee research. Her long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world.

Jane Goodall changed how we study animals, and since chimpanzees are our closest relatives, she also changed how we view ourselves. Even as a child, there were signs of her future as a biologist. One clear example occurred in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, she disappeared, prompting a search by the police, neighbors, and family. After a frantic search, she reappeared alone, with straw in her hair and clothes. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had hidden in a henhouse and stayed still for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the beginning of her journey as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voices of a playful 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to fans of children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as people who have seen computer programs about health and safety. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she explains, “so I had to quickly learn how to pronounce many medical terms.” 

Shirley shares what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even well-known ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there’s more to it. You need to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get the roles because they are too used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a traditional acting career. During the course, she occasionally sang jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she recalls, “the studio manager suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and surprisingly got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just fell into place for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult female actors often provide the voices for young boys and girls because their voices are lighter than those of male actors. Hiring child performers involves complicated procedures and lots of paperwork, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds and to vary her voices by watching children’s TV. 

Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my experience helps,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days of animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.”

The competition for voiceover work is intense, and having a good showreel – a recording that showcases what an artist can do – is very important. “It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley advises. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes her success – being near the top of her field – comes from determination as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and sharing it with film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also thinks a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and often becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over, and I’ll speak like that for hours or even days afterwards,” she explains. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in completely different voices.”

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many dream about as children, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and choose more practical careers, such as tax lawyer or auto parts manufacturer. The idea of making a living by drawing simple doodles, like those in high school notebooks, seems unrealistic. Yet, some people do manage to do this. 

Becoming a cartoonist is not the same for everyone, but most who succeed have wanted to be one for a long time. I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist, with a strong love for comic strips, contributing to school publications, and being known as "the kid who draws." I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to various companies. I was fortunate to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons about local issues. I created a few ideas, and they bought them. Within a few months, I was earning enough to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even advanced drawing skills. You just need your mind, your hand, and something to make marks with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. While the technical requirements are low, the job is still challenging. You should only pursue this career if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is much easier to find a regular job that pays the bills and allows time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living from your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I accept various jobs because you can learn a lot, even from work you may not enjoy. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

Now, let’s talk about the business side of being a cartoonist. In the past, many cartoonists could find steady jobs with different newspapers and magazines. However, those days are fading. Today, cartooning is often an entrepreneurial activity, meaning you not only have to create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with this process, the more successful you will be. I have seen many cartoonists with average creativity but strong business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack other skills.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ circle it, and write your name and the date next to it. However, the reality is that it is more likely no one will be interested in your work. If, by chance, someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster—it could actually be a lucky opportunity!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and decided to get rid of some things. One of the items I chose to throw away was an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a beautiful, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate throwing things away, so I was surprised by my decision. I took it to the dump and was about to leave it there when a young man approached me, looking confused. He asked, “You’re not really going to throw that away, are you?” I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could take it, and I agreed. After that day, I felt sad about my choice.

A few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I opened the email from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He told me, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had changed hands many times since I gave it away. Keith found my name and address on a label on the guitar and used it to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was overwhelmed with emotion and would have paid anything for it, but his price was very reasonable. I had forgotten that my dad always put name labels on my things, including the guitar. I could imagine my dad laughing at this strange situation.

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar when I was young, as it was popular in the 1970s. I loved the soothing sound of the classical guitar, which was easy for beginners to play. However, I struggled to improve, so I switched to the electric guitar and played simpler music. This was also the time of punk music, where anyone could become a rock star, even if they weren’t great musicians.

When I opened the box that Keith sent me and took out my old guitar, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt amazing; it was smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play but quickly stood up and put the strap over my shoulder, as electric guitars are meant to be played standing. My fingers instinctively knew where to go. I couldn’t explain the chords I wanted to play, but my hands remembered. My fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to form a chord. 

The electric guitar is not usually played alone, so now that I’m learning it again, I think I should form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or perhaps I can find others my age who have had similar experiences. We could call ourselves “The Regainers!”

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote my book, Insomniac, which focuses on people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was one of the few warning others about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and emotions. Many insomniacs I interviewed emphasized how essential sleep is for our overall well-being. Interestingly, those who have the most trouble sleeping often understand its importance the best. It’s encouraging to see sleep finally receiving the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. There hasn’t been much conversation about them. We often lose our dreams, especially when we wake up early and miss the last hour or two of sleep, which is primarily REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep—the stage where most dreams occur. Our most vivid and emotionally impactful dreams happen during REM sleep just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM, meaning that someone who lives to be 90 years old will spend around six or seven years dreaming in this state. When researchers prevent people from experiencing REM sleep, they find that the next night, the amount and intensity of REM sleep increases to make up for it. This suggests that dreams serve a purpose.

When REM sleep was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding our minds. However, later research did not support this idea, and the focus shifted to the physical causes of dreams rather than the psychological ones. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are significant. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams much better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person's interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as film is one of the most dream-like forms of art. However, I wondered if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively?

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and often surprising ways, using knowledge from our past and present to create new associations. They may assist us in discovering patterns and combinations that challenge our usual ways of thinking. For instance, Stickgold found that when people are awakened from REM sleep and asked to respond to a specific word, their answers are more original compared to when they are woken from other sleep stages. They tend to think outside the box and combine ideas in unexpected ways, which is a key aspect of creativity. Personally, I find that I write better after experiencing intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one that I can barely recall, seems to spark my creativity and provide inspiration. On those days, words and images flow so quickly that I can hardly keep up with my typing. I’m not sure how it works, but it does seem effective.

Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and everyone needs their brains to function at their best. We all need to think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, which has a stunning view of the sea, you see several empty frames on the walls, along with cheerful photos of her two daughters. As a leading artist in the copyist art movement, Susie can recreate the beauty of early 20th-century impressionist paintings and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. It seems unusual that she doesn’t keep any of her own work. “I don’t have any around,” Susie says casually. “As soon as I finish them, they go.” 

The reason is that Susie is highly sought after. Over her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted works by many famous artists, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that art experts often mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions at auctions, her copies range from a few hundred pounds to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie does not reveal most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. While many collectors genuinely love art, some are more interested in status. One celebrity enjoys showing off his “Van Gogh” painting, which is actually a “Susie Ray Van Gogh.” “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s their choice.” Some collectors even save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank and displaying Susie’s copy instead.

Susie is transparent about her work. When she copies a masterpiece, she aims to make it look as authentic as possible because she believes that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. However, she always signs her name on the back of the canvas. It is illegal to sell a copy as the real thing, and although she knows people who have profited from fakes, she has never been tempted. Those who create fakes often face serious consequences. Susie admits she isn’t wealthy and has faced challenges, but her situation is more stable now, and it wouldn’t be wise to risk her reputation with collectors and artists.

Susie didn’t start as a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. Looking back, she appreciates that experience because it helped her develop a passion for plants and taught her the importance of accuracy. She has no regrets about that time, but she is glad to have found a more financially rewarding career.

When younger artists seek her advice, Susie emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights how much she has studied to master her craft. Her training allows her to create everything from detailed plant drawings to perfect copies of 15th-century masterpieces and 20th-century abstract art, although she now focuses on French impressionists, particularly Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. 

Susie notes that many people think modern art is simple, almost like child’s play. However, she explains that while impressionists painted quickly and freely, they were also very precise, making their style challenging to replicate. Given her skills, it seems strange that Susie doesn’t create her own original art. Isn’t art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than her copies? She believes her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and she earns a good living from it. She has tried creating her own pieces, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—acceptable, but not impressive. It’s as if she has spent a lifetime enjoying gourmet meals and now finds it hard to settle for plain bread and water. Ultimately, Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing career, Ellen MacArthur was deeply passionate about the sea and being the fastest on it. This obsession began in her childhood. She felt a unique connection with the boats that took her around the world; they worked together as one. When she returned to land, everyday life felt unimportant. People were too curious about her races, and she quickly longed to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had almost defeated her.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop round-the-world race, she invited me to see the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher. This cabin had been her home, workplace, and survival space for 94 days. She explained how carefully she planned her supplies, even counting the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial for her. She proudly showed me her unappealing stock of foil-wrapped, freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her attention to detail in keeping the boat was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her entire world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen views the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, and fragile thing with limited resources. A significant moment for her was a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she participated in a bird survey for albatrosses. This experience made her reflect and see things in a new light. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. She felt that humanity often takes what it wants and moves on without considering the consequences.

When I arrived at Ellen’s office, she was finishing a heated conference call. She explained why we need to act now to protect the planet. “Coal, oil, and gas are no longer being made. They are valuable resources we have only once. We need to find ways to avoid wasting them.” Initially, her message was negative—encouraging people to use less—but she later realized there was a more positive approach. Now, she focuses on reusing materials, passionately discussing things like reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, speaking with government and business leaders about our dependence on non-renewable resources. “I will never be an expert,” she admits, “but I am like a sponge, absorbing information. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Compared to this, sailing felt selfish. This is about discovering how my voice can be most effective. It truly matters.”

Ellen also founded the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that collaborates with businesses and educational institutions to inspire young people to rethink and design a sustainable future. “I do miss the adventure of being at sea,” she says. “It defines who I am. You feel connected to everything around you, and there’s no time to feel lonely. You focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message is more complex than just saying, ‘I want to be the fastest around the world.’ While I may have been the fastest, this work is more important than anything I’ve ever done.”

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his time. He hopes to encourage other young people to explore the outdoors instead of just spending time on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero," and climbing Everest is just part of their plan. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to complete the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before turning thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish the challenge before he turns 14.

I spoke with several experienced Everest climbers, and none thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They agreed that while a young climber might be physically strong, they doubted whether a teenager could handle the emotional challenges. They also questioned how a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing.

The Romeros are aware of these concerns. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can't focus on it – we have a lot to do. We think about potential problems, of course. Karen and I constantly assess the risks, but we believe our experience as climbers will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming very strong and mature."

I also wonder about Jordan's reasons for wanting to climb. Is this just an ambitious father pushing his son too far? Paul insists, "This project isn’t about me seeking fame through my son’s achievements. At first, Jordan thought about doing this later in life, but we decided, ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him regularly to ensure he still wants to do it."

When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, "I just focus on achieving my goal." In the past, few people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting event. The more daring the record, the more attention it gets. This creates a challenge for Jordan. While we might think that focusing on achievements takes away from enjoyment, if he wants to inspire others, he must engage with the media. This means blogging, posing for photos, and giving interviews. He needs to offer something impressive, like climbing Everest.

Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop mountain climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Many people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I recently started a music degree, but my classmates know just as little about classical music as others our age. If someone doesn’t know who composed a piece, they probably don’t own any recordings of it. This situation must be disappointing for classical music lovers. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music events, and the average classical album sells only about 300 copies. I find this hard to believe. 

So, why is interest in classical music declining, even though it has existed for centuries? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games for this decline, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the main buyers of music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are in the minority. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure.

Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, can be challenging for us. We prefer fast conversations, quick actions, and rapid thoughts. Experts say we struggle to pay attention for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but just right for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Additionally, pop music often addresses topics that interest teenagers, while classical music usually does not have lyrics or relatable themes.

The way we listen to music has also changed. In the past, families would gather to play music together, and playing an instrument was highly valued. Now, we can find any music we want online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music playing in a store? One of my teachers says that audiences at classical concerts have increased recently. Maybe that’s true, but I doubt many of those new attendees are teenagers. In my orchestra, we perform classical music in various places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I’m not sure why middle-aged people are more drawn to classical concerts, but I do know that if teenagers’ parents love something, they often try to avoid it.

Some people blame schools for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many students are eager to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it’s not their preferred music outside of that. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we usually choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you regret I came here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother understood how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings scattered among the trees on a hillside; it looked confusing at first. Then she noticed signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved through the trees. “I wish you’d walk next to me instead of trailing behind like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, she stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll probably be kicked out soon anyway, so I might as well leave now.” She walked out of the building and headed towards the riding centre, following the sign. 

There was a charming old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around but saw no one. She approached the horses with a sense of respect. They were well cared for, and she noticed that almost every stall was occupied. She walked along, carefully observing each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. Then she stopped in front of the next horse. “But aren’t you the best one here!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” She read his name above the stall: Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. They can’t be far.” 

To her delight, the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. As she focused on putting the saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she climbed onto the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in control of everything around her. Her nickname at her old school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I’m serious; I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him to walk, then to trot. “If I stay here, I think we could become great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock, feeling exhilarated as a gentle breeze brushed against her cheek. She sensed that Maverick trusted her, and she was sure he would jump well.

I have met Cody Simpson before and have always admired his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So, how did a relaxed surfer end up performing in front of thousands of fans? Cody explains, “I first picked up a guitar when I was six and started writing songs at seven.” He remembers that swimming and surfing were his main interests back then. “I was 13 and in high school when I posted a few videos online.” 

These videos changed everything. He started by sharing a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans began to comment online, asking for more videos. Cody, who had recorded more songs at home, was happy to share them. The response was incredible. 

Cody was also a talented swimmer, training hard with top coaches to improve his skills. However, record labels began to show interest, and he faced a difficult decision: stay in Australia and continue swimming or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the leap. “It was very hard for me, especially at such a young age, to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?” 

He had to tell his swimming coach and friends about his move to the States. “It surprised most people. I’m the quiet kid,” he recalls, remembering their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy industry.” So, Cody packed his bags and traveled halfway around the world, giving up one dream to pursue another. 

Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn’t directly involved in his career, they support him from behind the scenes. Cody believes it’s important to have a close circle of good people around you to stay grounded. Everyone has moments of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How does my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight and travels the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how this affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.” 

Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big opportunity, even when it feels scary. “Everything happened so quickly and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m visiting countries I never thought I would see and performing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans. It’s something many people dream of achieving, but I know it won’t last forever.”

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I squinted and looked upstream at the sandbags, which were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags into place. Last week, I had worked long hours with most of the adults in town, showing that I could handle the job. My grandfather, however, didn’t seem to notice. 

With one hand still on the curtain, I scanned the half-mile stretch of dark water created by the release pipe from the wood processing factory in Milltown. On either side of the dark water were fragile ice shelves, and solid ice continued downstream. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I noticed a boy on the far side of the river. I didn’t recognize him. I frowned as I saw him trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from an expedition in South America. This chain is more special to me than having a famous grandfather, as only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that journey, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen.

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training session. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his bedroom. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you off to?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious from my wetsuit, and he had seen me in my kayak every morning. I tried to ignore his temper, but it was getting harder. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His harsh words hit me hard, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came over with a sympathetic smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself at the moment,” I finished for her. I held back from saying he had always been like this. But like my mom, I tried to be understanding. When I was younger, he was my hero, especially when he showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine. Those old photos still hang framed on his wall, along with his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own face in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, this grumpy old man. 

My mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his bedroom more. Have a good training session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even in this cold weather!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America if I find sponsors for my expedition.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and headed downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I quickly walked towards the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her into the study, where she saw an unframed painting on the table, leaning against the wall. It was clearly one of Grandpa's works, but it looked different from his usual style and was obviously unfinished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." 

Jess looked closely at the painting. It showed a river that took up most of the scene; it wasn't a river she recognized, and it might not even be real, just a fantasy. The painting was strange and beautiful in a haunting way. The riverbank was barely visible, with just a hint of green that was easy to overlook, drawing the eye into the pale waters and towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people in the painting, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she found it captivating, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice that seemed too casual, revealing her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings; he just painted them and let others interpret them. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: "River Boy." The words felt strangely significant to her, but she couldn't explain why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "But there is no boy." 

"Exactly. It's strange, isn't it? For him to be so specific. But since he hasn't finished it yet, maybe he plans to add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." 

"Mum! You should have known better." 

"I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can probably guess his response." 

Jess didn't need to guess; she knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not the artist's job to explain a painting because each one has its own life and language, just like a poem. We either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to every fool..." 

"Ignoramus, he said." 

"...every ignoramus what it means. If artists had to explain their work to everyone who asked, they would never get anything done. And he said..." Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him." 

"Inspire?" 

"Yes, someone who motivates an artist." Jess understood the term. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually meant that the muse wasn't helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a tough part to work on. He never suggested that the muse was her. In fact, she always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally gone into the carpet and made a big cut. I’m not claiming that this actually happened, just that it could have. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the moment, as often happens. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This kind of thing happens to me quite often. I feel unlucky in that way.

What I was really trying to do was find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved from her house to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and it has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and milkmaids. Now, I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, so I was excited when she gave it to me!

The problem is, it’s a corner cabinet, which means it has to fit in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom belongs to Mum and Dad, the back one is my sister Angela’s, the little one over the garage is my brother Tom’s, and my room is the size of a broom cupboard. Mum says that when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. Then, when Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I’ll be stuck in my broom cupboard for a long time. I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only issue is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. 

I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. I thought, if I can’t cut anything off the cabinet, why not cut a hole in the carpet? It seemed like a simple solution. Dad calls this kind of thinking “lateral thinking.” I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to “think outside the box.” And that’s exactly what I was doing!

The novel "The Borrowers" tells the story of a tiny family living secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They survive by "borrowing" items from the larger humans around them. When I was asked to direct a TV adaptation of this novel, I knew it would be challenging to meet the expectations of fans. People who love the book have strong opinions about how it should be portrayed. To avoid criticism, I relied on the original illustrations from the book. The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, which made filming more complicated.

A key aspect was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on their borrowing adventures, we had to position the camera ten times further away than usual. To capture their perspective, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from a height of no more than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans doing this! We only raised the cameras for aerial shots.

One major challenge was creating realistic shadows when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized surroundings. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous director George Lucas called to ask how we achieved it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with oversized objects to make the actors appear small. It was wonderfully surreal. I remember asking them to carry giant scissors, and they really embraced the idea. The coins we used were larger than dinner plates and hard to lift, often making the crew laugh, which sometimes interrupted filming.

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to be pushed down a tunnel with hoses, and they found it so scary that they didn’t need to act. Getting the costumes right was also important to me, as other directors had struggled with this in previous adaptations. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas to give them a doll-like appearance, which made it difficult for the lead actress to move. She couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug to avoid a smooth look. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail with the costumes!

Most of the action outside the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. This made it hard for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of each scene to show the team how they should look, and by the end, I had created 2,000 sketches. They weren’t perfect, but they were helpful. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly; I once filmed an entire scene only to realize there was no film in the camera. In the end, everything came together, and I believe the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there are none. I know that soon the chaos will start. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones who will ask for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life of touring and tutors. While the rest of the band is renting here for recording, we are staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet regular kids. I want to meet someone whose mom works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so cool and normal.

I walk into the school’s main office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary seems confused. “Oh,” she says, typing my last name on her keyboard. That’s one good thing; few people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” she replies. Then she tears the sheet and hands it to me. English Literature, first period. Great, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. But I’ll be late. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map the night before so I wouldn’t look foolish searching for my classes.

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher taking attendance. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and take a seat in the last desk of the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my very normal outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. No one will suspect me now! “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I glance down at my expensive shoes with embroidered flowers. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I reply. The teacher pauses. “Desert... McGraw?” she says carefully. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and eventually gives us our course outlines. After discussing the books we need to read this year, she actually lets us socialize! All teachers should understand how important this is.

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few options. Should I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or should I share what my dad says? “We need a change, Desert,” he told me, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Essence? I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a studio right by the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, lies are easier. “What does he do?” she asks. Whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I can pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, fiddling with my backpack zipper. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care. Perfect.

Not only is the average American teenage girl expected to be the president of the Student Council, but she also needs to have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America today. Both boys and girls cannot just go to school and blend in; being average is no longer enough. Mediocrity is not acceptable, and lacking ambition is seen as laziness. 

Kristen Loose, a teenager, points out that many adults forget how much pressure teenagers face today. They have a lot of homework, tests, extracurricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to maintain a social life. Despite these stresses being common, negative stereotypes about teenagers still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes include being lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these descriptions, many believe it is unfair to label an entire generation this way.

Kristen Loose argues that many people assume teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She acknowledges that she often has her phone nearby, but not for trivial reasons. For her, it is a tool that helps make life easier, not just a way to text friends. Today, students are expected to have quick access to information and to be reachable at all times, which can create the impression of a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere, and schoolwork now requires attention around the clock.

Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish their activities after midnight. Their schedules are packed with school, extracurricular activities, family responsibilities, and homework. They then have to wake up and do it all over again the next day, often getting less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of American teenagers get the recommended amount of sleep, and 28 percent admitted to falling asleep in school at least once a week due to lack of sleep.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen believes that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen rarely spends her free time on social media or watching TV; instead, she dedicates her energy to volunteer work. She feels that the stereotype of teenagers is that they are self-centered and only care about their own interests. However, she enjoys volunteering and looks forward to making a positive impact in her school and community.

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these views and contribute positively to the world. There will always be a new generation of students making a difference before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This ongoing science project combines astronomy with adventure, which is likely why teenagers are drawn to it. I joined them one weekend in late spring as they prepared to release a high-altitude balloon to capture images of shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece from space enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a bright trail.

As night falls, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside, there is a camera, an altitude measuring device, and a thermometer to track temperature changes during the ascent. Two GPS trackers are placed on the outside of the lunch box to help them find it later. They use a gas tank, donated by a supporter from a nearby state, to inflate the balloon, which gradually expands to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour round trip to get the tank, but he didn’t mind. For these kids, such efforts are normal.

Finally, it’s time for lift-off. They count down, “Five, four, three, two, one,” and the balloon starts to rise. Some of the teenagers run after it, using powerful flashlights to track its path in the dark sky. There is a moment of silence and a shared sense of wonder as the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets on the mountainside, looking at a sky so clear that it’s hard to believe they are only four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city with around 4 million people. I see a boy climb into a sleeping bag and quickly fall asleep. “We’re the only ones talking,” one girl whispers. “I know,” replies another. Suddenly, a meteor streaks across the sky.

As the balloon rises, the air pressure decreases, causing it to expand until it is almost the size of a house. Then it pops with a loud bang. A parachute ensures that the equipment inside the lunch box lands safely back on Earth. The students will retrieve it the next day using the GPS trackers. Finding it is not easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in a remote area. “Recoveries are a big part of the program,” says the group’s leader, noting they have only lost two lunch boxes in 53 launches. “This journey helps us get to know the landscape in a way we normally wouldn’t.”

On this occasion, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop, but the recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountains. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or stuck in a tall tree. “These students are familiar with the Eastern Sierra,” their leader explains. “What seems wild to some is just a normal part of life for others.” In the end, it took them 11 hours to find the lunch box, which was in a canyon on a flat rock near a waterfall. Unfortunately, the camera did not capture any shooting stars. While this was disappointing, it provided a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and their effects above mountain ridges. It also became another exciting story to share with anyone who asks.

Chloe Morgan admits that she was not very interested in science, especially Palaeontology, until she turned fifteen. Her interest began by chance when her younger brother became fascinated with dinosaurs, a phase many children go through. Although she initially dismissed his interest, she helped him with a science project and discovered an article about recent findings in Palaeontology that amazed her. From that moment, she knew she wanted to pursue this field.

I asked Chloe about the support she received, as Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people at that time. She recalled meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already well-known despite his young age. Chloe felt nervous at first, worried that he might see her as just an annoying kid. However, she felt more comfortable when he showed patience and listened to her questions.

I also asked her about how palaeontologists are portrayed in movies and TV shows. Chloe expressed her frustration, noting that films like Jurassic Park, which feature dinosaurs created with special effects, have increased public interest in dinosaurs but not necessarily in Palaeontology itself. She feels that palaeontologists are often shown as either eccentric geniuses or socially awkward individuals, which does not reflect the reality of their work.

Chloe explained that her job is very diverse. She spends a lot of time digging for dinosaur bones, but she also works long hours in laboratories analyzing fossils and writing scientific papers. Although it is not always part of her job, she believes it is important to communicate scientific findings to the public, especially to young people. She wants to help them understand science better and inspire their interest in the natural world, starting with dinosaurs.

The recent TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs gave Chloe a chance to influence how dinosaurs are shown on screen. She mentioned that the producers were knowledgeable, and her role was mainly to ensure that the dinosaurs were accurately represented in terms of size and shape, and that they lived during the same time period. The documentary attracted viewers of all ages because it presented dinosaurs in a way that was much more realistic than in movies like Jurassic Park.

When I asked Chloe why dinosaurs continue to captivate us and remain a focus of research, she suggested that they appeal to our natural curiosity and desire for exploration. Dinosaurs remind us that there is still much to discover in our world, and Palaeontology offers a unique way to explore the past.

When you travel by car with your family, even if you are just six years old, you probably know that you are not “there yet,” even if you keep asking, “Are we there yet?” The truth is, once you arrive, it’s not “there” anymore; it’s “here.” So if you think you might be “there,” you should really be asking, “Are we here yet?” 

Parents often wish they were “there” more than anyone else, especially when they hear that question repeatedly during long trips. Think about it: wouldn’t you rather relax in the back seat, with no responsibilities? You could watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles while enjoying the beautiful views outside. Meanwhile, one of your parents is in the front seat, managing snacks and the radio, making sure everything runs smoothly.

But then, something unexpected happens—usually caused by my younger brother, Tim. He might put his foot on my side of the seat, which is not okay! I respond by putting my foot on his side, and soon we’re both fighting for space. Our parents have to intervene, telling Tim to stay in his own seat and keep his hands to himself. This calms things down for a bit, and we can enjoy the scenery again.

Later, while I’m trying to read, I suddenly feel a draft on my arm. The window isn’t open, so where is it coming from? Tim is next to me, quietly blowing air in my direction. He’s not touching me, so he thinks he’s being clever. This makes me angry, and soon he gets yelled at again, causing more chaos in the car. 

Over the years, Dad has come up with ways to handle our questions. When we ask, “Are we there yet?” he often replies, “Yes, we’re here. Get out of the car.” When we point out that we are still driving, he says, “Oh, then maybe we’re not there yet.” This usually keeps us quiet for a while. 

You can tell you’ve finally arrived when the adults quickly exit the car to get away from the kids after a long journey. So remember: if your parents are still close enough to answer your question, the answer is no, you’re not there yet.

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where customers can enjoy coffee and cake while playing board games. They hope that people will love the experience and want to come back. Zuzi explains their motivation: “There’s so much technology today. Everyone is busy with their phones and gadgets. We wanted to bring people together in a way that doesn’t involve staring at screens. It’s natural for people to connect and communicate with each other.”

The café features games called ‘Eurogames,’ which have gentle themes like farming and building landscapes. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, created by German designer Klaus Teuber. In this game, players build settlements on an island and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged until the end, so no one feels left out. This idea was further developed in ‘co-operative’ games, where all players either win or lose together, encouraging more social interaction. One popular co-operative game is Pandemic, designed by North American Matt Leacock, who was inspired by a Eurogame called Lord of the Rings. Leacock recalls, “When I played that with friends, we felt scared and excited. In the end, everyone felt good, whether they won or lost. I wanted to create something similar.”

Leacock’s love for board games started when he was a child. He enjoyed receiving games as gifts but often felt disappointed when they didn’t meet his expectations. With help from his uncle, he began redesigning games to make them better. Pandemic became a huge success, and its follow-up introduced even more storytelling elements. Leacock explains, “It’s like an electronic game where you develop characters, learn new rules, and the world changes. It tells a story.”

Interestingly, the rise of video games has helped modern board games become popular. Many people now play games on their smartphones, making them more open to trying board games. Ben Hogg, who works for a leading games company, says, “Everyone plays mobile games now. Most people with smartphones have at least one game they enjoy.” 

For a while, video games allowed for social interaction in places like arcades or through multiplayer games at home. However, as multiplayer games moved online, players became more isolated. This led some people to seek out board games to play with others in person. As seen in John and Zuzi's busy café, tabletop gaming has become more than just entertainment. In our increasingly online world, games are now a way to connect and share experiences in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest hits in the UK in recent years. His story shows that endurance and persistence are crucial in the music industry, even if your career starts with many setbacks. He describes his mother as ‘an amazing singer’ who encouraged him to play the guitar. The only radio station he listened to at home was a local one aimed at middle-aged listeners, which influenced his musical taste as he grew up. He was 12 years old when he first heard a contemporary song. Around the same time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room learning songs on the piano. He recalls, “I was doing well in tennis, but it wasn’t what I wanted to do for my life.
