It was just too much hard work.” At 17, he left school to pursue a career as a performer. He formed a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but didn’t share his passion for performing. Jamie remembers breaking down in front of his parents, telling them he wanted to pursue music, explaining that he had been writing lyrics during economics lessons and practicing the piano every day while others played outside. His father gave him 18 months to succeed; if he didn’t, he would need to find a job. After several close calls with record labels, he was signed by a music publisher at 19 based on one song. However, record labels wanted him to be a solo artist, so he had to part ways with his friend. Ultimately, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album, but fame did not come immediately. He reflects, “I feel like I’ve been in the wrong place at the wrong time for much of my artist career, but as a writer, I’ve been in the right place at the right time.” Writing for other artists is where he truly found his success. He believes he is one of the main writers in the UK that labels turn to for new artists, helping them launch their careers. Sometimes, he has to reassure the artists he works with that aiming for chart success is not something to be ashamed of. He asks them, “Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?” He emphasizes that they should aim to create something amazing that will also sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone in pop music speak openly about wanting to write hit songs. Jamie is not arrogant; he simply understands that he wants to write number-one hits and has the talent to do so. Instead of worrying about how others perceive him, he focuses on his goals. He states, “When I go into the studio with someone, we need to aim for global success and write the best music of the next year. It’s not just about what’s trendy; we want to create classic modern pop songs.”

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very popular online, but many people, like me, may not know him because we don’t watch videos of people doing bike stunts. He is known as a ‘street trials cyclist.’ This means he jumps from difficult places, like roofs or walls, to land safely in other challenging spots. These stunts are recorded and shared online.

When I interview him, we meet at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local kids recognize him, and even some older people come to greet him, calling him ‘an absolute legend.’ After watching him perform, I agree with them. I came with some doubts, but I am impressed by his bravery, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains what he plans to do, and I often find it hard to believe he can succeed. However, when I compliment him afterward, he seems uninterested and a bit down.

Despite his online fame, Tony says he is not comfortable with being a celebrity. He finds the social aspect challenging. He understands the importance of connecting with fans, but he prefers to focus on doing stunts rather than talking about them. This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and the small cameras that capture his stunts. He reflects, “This technology allows people like me to earn a living.” He feels that many people are always recording themselves or looking at screens, and he doesn’t fully agree with that.

Tony is not complaining, though. He makes a good income from his videos, which would have just been a hobby for someone in the past. After years of interviewing top athletes, I’ve learned that two key factors turn a passionate child into a top competitor: energy and the ability to handle emotional disappointment. These traits can be more important than talent and help someone keep going despite failures. In risky sports, it’s even more important to have mental strength.

Even at the park, Tony fell a few times on what he considered easy but new challenges. He simply got back up and kept trying until he succeeded. Not everyone sees him as a hero. Some people think he is reckless and takes too many risks. He responds, “Those who criticize me may care, but they don’t understand. They probably have never ridden a trials bike and don’t know the sport. They don’t realize I get advice from experts to reduce risks.”

In reality, Tony is careful about the risks he takes. He explains, “People are different. Some never feel scared, and they shouldn’t be doing these sports. It’s important to recognize the dangers. The rest of us can be divided into those who can overcome fear and those who can’t. I belong to the group that feels fear but finds a way to move past it. I’m not addicted to risk; I spend a lot of time planning and preparing. Sometimes, I ride around for a while to get in the right mindset before trying a new stunt. I know I must stay calm just before I jump. If I fully commit, I’ll be fine.”

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on many dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, which is a long, thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net; she only had a belt around her waist connected to another wire above her. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick that weighed eight kilograms. 

Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Although she had some circus skills, she found that high-wire walking was very different. “The training was a shock,” Helen said. “I didn’t realize how strong I needed to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and then another hour practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so I could keep going if I slipped. Every time I fell, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I got nervous and started shaking, the wire would shake too!”

On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen focused on taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took her 15 minutes. “That was the scariest thing I’ve done,” she said afterward. “I’m glad it’s over!” Despite this experience, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by skiing, kiting, and biking.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old-style bicycle with one large wheel and one small wheel. He had previously written a book about his travels in Canada using a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motorsport and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and even used it for a holiday in Amsterdam. He said, "That trip opened my eyes," and decided he wanted to explore the world by bike. Instead of a regular touring bike, he wanted to create one himself. He thought the most unique bike would be a penny farthing, so he visited a museum to learn how they were made.

After two attempts in 2001 and 2003, which ended because of a knee injury, he finally began his journey in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries across four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. Although he met cyclists who could ride up mountains, which he couldn’t do, he never regretted choosing the penny farthing. The further he traveled from home, the more people were amazed by his bike.

His toughest experience was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream, which made him very sick. He spent ten days in a hostel without medicine and had no money for a hospital or to return home. Despite these challenges, Jeff now says, "If I could afford it, I would start traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing."

I work at a university in the US with my team, and we are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have recently started using a new tool called a ‘night-vision scope’ that helps us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about the black duck population because their numbers have decreased significantly, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. 

We have a lot of information about their activities during the day, but we know very little about what they do at night because we did not have the right equipment. This new scope will give us clear images, even on nights without a moon, allowing us to learn more and make better decisions about how to protect their habitat.

Our work is challenging. There are four of us, and each of us works six hours a day. We have studied ducks in various locations, and I have had to take a boat to some sites to record every duck I see. The weather has been difficult; some nights are mild, but many are rainy. It is so quiet that I have needed a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one workday because the snow was too deep for our special vehicles. 

Despite the challenges, I enjoy this work, especially when I think about the summer ahead, which will involve long hours in a laboratory analyzing our findings. Being indoors will be tough, but it is necessary. I wouldn’t change this experience for anything!

Whenever I tell people about my job, they often find it hard to believe that it exists. But I’m serious! I spend my workdays tasting chocolate! This is a crucial part of ensuring that customers receive perfect, high-quality chocolate from my company. Each week, I get samples, which are small amounts of chocolate from our factory, and I need to evaluate them for taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw ingredients we typically use, like nuts and fruit, to select the best ones for our chocolate. 

Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I can test and taste the products I create, and I enjoy sharing samples with my colleagues! My kitchen is equipped with machines and ingredients, making it a fun place to work. It’s great to have a private area to escape to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I work in our food lab, and other times I travel abroad to buy raw materials, which can be challenging since I have a young family. However, I love the variety and lack of routine in my job, although I think the chocolate itself is the best part!

People often ask me if I ever get bored of chocolate. I’ve been working with it for a long time, and I’ve never felt tired of eating it. In fact, I often go home and enjoy more chocolate in the evening!

Have you ever thought about what it’s like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson works at Circus Experience, a center that teaches young people circus skills. She says her course is popular because it offers many different skills, such as juggling, throwing and catching objects like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air in front of an amazed audience. 

During the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can attend some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “To have a career in the circus, performers need to avoid doing the same thing repeatedly – it’s essential to keep performances exciting and dynamic. If you want to succeed in the circus, you must keep practicing. Another great aspect is the friendships formed with other performers and the opportunity to learn from them. Staying fit is also very important – circus artists, like athletes, train every day to stay strong. While training is crucial, the best performers are those who are determined to succeed, have creativity, and continuously work on improving their skills. 

People often think that injuries are common or that you only work for a short time each year. However, the real challenge is planning for the future because you can only perform while you’re young, and then you need to think about other career options.” The course also includes lessons on business planning. Many former students have started their own businesses around the world and are happy to share their experiences. However, Sophia cautions that it’s not a profession for making a lot of money! “The work usually doesn’t provide a regular salary. It’s also very competitive – but it’s a lot of fun!”

You may not know her name or face, but you have likely heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer, which means she sings in the background to support the lead singer. Some people think backing singers are not as talented as lead singers, but that is not true; they often have to be even more skilled. People like Mariam are the true stars of the music industry!

“What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I will be asked to sing,” she explains. “It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Sometimes, it might even be a silly tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I am often surprised by what producers ask for. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never complain; I just do my job!”

“Excellent musical skills are crucial for my work, along with the ability to learn quickly. Often, there is no sheet music to follow. I will never forget my first experience recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different part, along with an orchestra. I was really nervous; I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are already long enough!”

“One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers sometimes do not know which musical range works best for a female voice. By listening to me sing their song, they can figure out how to improve it.”

Julie Deane started with only basic knowledge of fashion but built a successful business selling ‘satchels,’ which are traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous stores and are popular among many celebrities. Before deciding to sell satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, such as cake decorating and party planning, instead of just going with her first thought. When she chose to focus on satchels, not everyone supported her idea. Julie recalls, “Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced.” She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had never had a career but had a natural talent for business. The design of the satchels was inspired by children’s storybooks.

Although Julie was not familiar with fashion blogs, they played a key role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, she sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would write about them in their blogs. They did, and interest in her products grew, along with the speed at which her company produced the satchels. Julie now enjoys seeing which celebrity is photographed with a satchel!

While other companies spend money on online ads, Julie uses the internet community to gather ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied her satchel design to sell similar products. Because of this, she now ensures she has confidence in her production team, just as she does in her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices, where people enjoy working. There is now a new factory, and while the buildings are important, it is the team that makes the workplace special.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents allowed her and her brother Jamie to choose how they spent their free time. Vicky enjoyed participating in various sports. She was a talented swimmer, and her coach believed she had the potential to become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard for her to balance training with her schoolwork.

As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and began competing. Vicky found this exciting and decided to try cycling too. She later said it was the best choice she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and performing well. The cycling track was close to her school, so attending training sessions after school was easy for her. Vicky eventually had a successful career in track cycling, winning several competitions. However, when she turned 28, she decided to retire from competitive cycling. She explained, “For years, I loved winning, but I started to feel tired of it all. When the excitement fades, it loses its meaning. Fortunately, I found a new career.”

Vicky began working for a charity called CycleZone. She explained, “We help young people who have never enjoyed sports. Our first step is to teach them how to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does important work and brings young people together, creating a sense of community.” The charity uses celebrities to promote its activities. Vicky mentioned, “Some people doubt that celebrity support is always beneficial for a charity. They argue that celebrities may be more interested in their own image, which can overshadow the charity's real work. However, if famous singers and actors can help, I believe they should.”

Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson grew up in Ireland. Even though her parents were not musicians, music was always present in her home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother how to play. The first time Ana sang in front of an audience was at school, but she was so nervous that her teacher had to take her off the stage. This teacher suggested that she join the school theatre club to build her confidence. After participating in the club for some time, she happily sang with 50 other students at an end-of-term concert.

A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, "Falling Stars," in just three days and enjoyed it so much that she signed up for a songwriting course led by a professional. Although she was the youngest student, she already knew more about music than many of her classmates. However, Ana felt that the teacher did not listen to her ideas, which inspired her to write the song "Something to Say" about her frustration. She shared this song online, and it became very popular. She was thrilled to receive comments from people who loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened.

Joss Alton, the owner of a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled from the other side of Ireland to invite her to join the company. At first, Ana was uncertain because she did not know much about Isotope and did not want anyone telling her what to sing. However, Joss assured her that this would not happen. Soon after, she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope, and all the tickets sold out quickly, making it a wonderful evening.

Ana prefers to write songs about difficult times rather than happy moments, as she feels there is more to express during tough times. One of her favorite songs is "Decision," which reflects on why her brother stopped singing for a while and how unhappy it made him. While she hopes her fans will enjoy her music, her main goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an incredible trip – a guided boat tour along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He is a journalist like me and wanted to write articles about the journey. He loves boats, which is not something I share with him. However, I had always dreamed of visiting this area since I saw it on TV as a child, especially because it was where our great-grandparents lived before moving to Europe. I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally said yes!

A few days before our departure, there were storms in the area we were visiting. Fortunately, the weather forecast for our trip was good, predicting calm seas. I was busy with work and didn’t have much time to prepare, but Harry assured me he would handle everything, so I stopped worrying.

After arriving in Canada, we met the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide told us that very few people live along that coast, and indeed, the only other creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We could see islands in the distance, but the morning fog made it hard to see far, so I focused on the beautiful patterns our boat created in the water.

We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches. They were filled with colorful fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was wonderful to forget about how fast or slow the day was going. We always remembered to prepare lunch and dinner together over campfires. Each evening, when we fell asleep on the boats, even though the beds were hard, it felt like a stress-free life!

When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I go back to normal life? But I knew I would miss my family and friends if I stayed. I was also excited to share our adventures with everyone back home!

My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. When I was a child, I watched many of his games. You might think that this would make me love basketball, but it actually did the opposite. I enjoyed telling my friends how great my dad was, especially when he won, but I often brought a book to read instead of watching the games.

When I started secondary school, I was still two years away from being a teenager, but I was already two meters tall. Because of my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I liked the training sessions, but I thought I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, my teacher believed in me more than I believed in myself. After some time, I agreed to play, and a few weeks later, I found myself in a game against another school. My parents watching made me more nervous, but it turned out fine!

For the next four years, I practiced every day and did very well, even joining an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA when I was fifteen. The coach there trained Olympic basketball players, and it was amazing to learn from him. However, I didn’t enjoy being away from my parents at first. At home, I hadn’t spent much time with friends because of all the training, so that part wasn’t too different for me. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly too!

I became a professional player at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most players in the professional league since I was fifteen, but I needed to gain weight to match my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted that decision.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college, but I needed a part-time job because my course was quite expensive. After thinking about different options, I decided to train as a weekend tour guide in my hometown, Chicago, USA. I took visitors around the city and was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I saw the city I had lived in my whole life from a tourist's perspective, and it felt like a new experience each time!

After I finished my studies, I chose to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be easy, but when I looked into it, I realized I needed to learn a lot more to get a license. All tour guides in Chicago must answer many questions about the city, including its architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging but interesting months, I earned my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent guide.

Being a tour guide is not just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group in crowds. You also need other important skills. You should be entertaining and able to tell interesting stories. Most importantly, you must adapt to unexpected situations, like if a place you planned to visit is closed or if the route changes. Tourists want to enjoy a well-organized tour, not hear about problems or what they are missing.

I need to ensure that visitors are happy with my tours, as negative reviews online can harm my business. Like most tour guides, I understand that good reviews attract more customers. That’s why it’s essential to make tours enjoyable and stress-free. I believe that my enthusiasm and energy in my job lead to very positive reviews, and many visitors recommend my tours to others coming to Chicago.

My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I traveled to Thailand for two weeks with my sister, Josie. Even though she is five years younger than me, we have a good relationship. We went to volunteer at an elephant sanctuary, which is a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would connect with the other volunteers because they were much older than us. We were also nervous since it was our first experience doing something like this. However, we ended up having a great time.

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to gather food for the elephants. They eat a lot of grass and banana plants, so this took most of our day. Josie found it quite challenging, but seeing the elephants enjoy their meals made it worthwhile for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river using large brushes and soap. I found this very enjoyable, even though I ended up getting wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they would spend the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a bedroom, which was a bit cramped, but we chose to do this because Josie didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we were prepared for that. The meals were delicious and did not include meat, which we both don’t like.

After dinner, all the volunteers and staff would spend the evenings talking and playing games. Now that we are back in the UK, Josie doesn’t often mention Thailand. However, if someone asks her if she enjoyed her time at the sanctuary, she says she loved it. I’m not sure she is being completely honest, though. I think she might feel a bit frustrated with herself for not fully enjoying her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she reflects on the experience, she realizes how fortunate she was to go. Maybe she will return one day – I definitely will!

My name is Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We sell flowers not just to individuals for gifts or home decoration, but also to various businesses. Hotels and offices often use flowers in their reception areas, and we sometimes provide flowers for business photo shoots. Once, I even decorated a castle for a wedding, which was a lot of work, but I felt very proud of the result.

My day begins at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep at that time, and my friends think I’m a bit crazy, but I love what I do. It can be quite cold and dark, but I don’t let that bother me. The flower market is amazing, filled with flowers from around the world. The beautiful sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were picking flowers for myself, I would choose only pink ones, as that is my favorite color. However, I have to remember that my preferences may not match what my customers want. 

Sometimes, it’s difficult to find the flowers that customers request because not all flowers are available year-round. I don’t enjoy negotiating prices with the flower sellers, but it’s part of the job. Flowers can be expensive, so I always try to get the best price I can. 

When I return to the shop, we review customer orders and arrange the flowers I bought into vases. Then, we create flower bouquets and calculate the costs of the orders. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes need to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some might think this is too much effort, but I enjoy figuring out how to create the best flower arrangements within a customer’s budget. That’s what selling is all about, and I wouldn’t want to do anything else!

My city has a modern cinema that shows the latest films and many children's movies on weekends. It is close to my home, but a year ago, I realized I wanted something more – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, I started a film club with two friends! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we choose a different location in the city each month. For instance, we rented an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which created a great atmosphere for the movie, and it was fantastic! Some places we use are even free because the owners sell snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We are happy to cover our costs without aiming for profit. Each time we show a film, it gets easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We can track ticket sales online, so we no longer worry about empty seats! There is always a lot to do, but it feels wonderful when people of all ages tell us how much they enjoyed the experience. Our website has been very helpful, and we are now connected with other film clubs across the country. We have visited them to learn how they operate, but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We also started a blog because we know most people look online for film information instead of reading local reviews. We have tried putting up posters in cafés, but nothing is as effective as word of mouth – when people recommend us to their friends. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film; last month, we had a movie quiz that everyone enjoyed.

Taking photographs was always my favorite activity as a child. When I turned 15, I wanted to take my hobby further, so I started a special project: I would take one photograph every day for a whole year. Many young photographers had done this before, but I thought it was a great idea, so I began.

After a few weeks, I decided to share my photos on a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and show my work to others. I was surprised to find that people liked my perspective and the way I captured images. I enjoyed photographing many different subjects. Then, someone suggested that if my photos had a common theme, my project would be even better. I agreed and decided to focus on nature, especially birds and the sky.

Most of my photos were in black and white, which was different from what many other young photographers were doing, as they preferred color. This made me doubt my project at times, and I almost gave up. However, I learned to trust my feelings and became more confident in my style and choices.

One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for my age group, so I entered some of my photos just for fun. I will never forget the moment when the judges announced that I had won first prize. I was incredibly happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized that my photography might be good enough for a professional career. Now, I have my own photography studio, and I have never regretted my choice of career.

I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because I wanted to try new activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking. These were things I had never done before. In the NYC, you can participate in various activities that challenge you, and you are always learning. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called ‘leaders’. When you complete each level, you receive a certificate.

When I first joined, my leader suggested that my first challenge should be to help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had joined that same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was quite shy, and the other children already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. However, I decided to accept the challenge because I wanted to earn my first NYC certificate. 

Soon, I found myself wanting to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became much more important to me than just getting the certificate. After I completed the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had formed great relationships with the children. Now, I spend about four hours a week there, and I always look forward to it.

Because of what I’ve learned at the children’s club, I have decided that when I finish school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. I had never thought about this career before starting at the club. In fact, I had never considered my future job, and the idea of youth work had never crossed my mind. This experience has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I now have several NYC certificates, and one of them is for camping!

I was born in Denver, USA, and I started snowboarding when I was eight years old. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The slope looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try it. At that age, I hadn’t thought about asking him to start snowboarding, but he loved it and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it seem easy, and eventually, I did well. After that first experience, I quickly grew to love the sport and improved my skills. I began competing when I was ten. Some people enter many competitions and lose interest in snowboarding, but my passion for participating and winning has only grown stronger over the years, which motivates me to work harder.

I like not having a strict plan, and sometimes this works out well. For example, I became the first female to score a perfect 100 at a local competition. I didn’t think I would attempt the jumps that earned me that score until I actually started. That achievement boosted my confidence in my abilities. In the summer, I focus on training and my studies since there’s no snow. Even though I train every day, it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like I do in winter. I also get to spend a lot of time with my friends, which helps me cope with not being able to do what I love most.

I need to think about my future carefully. Snowboarding is a big part of my life now, but I believe it’s important to have another option in case I don’t succeed as a professional snowboarder or if I get injured. I’m considering whether becoming a doctor is a possibility, depending on whether my active lifestyle allows me to pursue a college degree. I can’t imagine ever getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever.

When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had, and I never thought about the future. For example, I didn’t know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I thought I should have one too. My parents said I could only get it if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I am very grateful to my parents for this because it taught me an important lesson. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn’t enjoy it much, so my parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it too. I never thought it would be so easy, as it looked complicated when I watched my mum. My friends thought it sounded boring, but I was excited about it. My mum showed me that I could create something beautiful at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first pieces of jewellery to my friends and family as soon as I finished making them. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. Even though I appreciated their support, I needed to be sure that my jewellery would be popular with others. The only way to find out was to rent a market stall with my mum. There are many tourists where I live, and they bought a lot of my jewellery to take home. Soon, we started receiving calls from all over the country from people wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company with many employees, but in reality, it was just my mum and me at the market! That’s when I realized my business could succeed, and I decided to create a website. Since then, I have made thousands of pounds from my business, mostly online, but we still have our market stall. It has been a lot of fun so far.

When Janine Stuart was just 13 years old, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. The book is partly inspired by Janine’s own life. In an interview, she explained, “Because my father’s job made us move around a lot, I learned how to make new friends easily. I know what it feels like to be the new student in a class, which helped me write about Amelia’s experiences in a new school. Some of the funniest moments in the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I’m an only child, I had to use my imagination to create that.” 

Janine began writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it felt natural for Janine to spend her time this way. The year before, she had won a short story competition on a young writers’ website. This success made the publishing company eager to read her finished novel. They loved it, and a year later, Being Amelia was available in bookstores.

One review of the book notes that, despite the cheerful images of teenagers on the cover, the characters face real challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer also mentions that even though Janine is young and her novel is not very long, she has shown that she is a better writer than many bestselling authors. 

Janine is still adjusting to her fame: “At first, I would hide when people recognized me in the street, but now I’m fine with it. I want to help other young writers, but they need to discover their own style. For me, I just need to spend time with my friends, and I’ll find something interesting to write about!”

My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. Three years ago, my family and I moved into a castle on a small island. This happened because my father was invited to manage the castle. He works for an organization that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open for visitors. He was excited about this opportunity, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that he should accept the job. We were worried about what life on the island would be like. We knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our cozy home across the water, and there was no school nearby.

However, once we moved, we quickly adapted to island life. The castle itself isn’t particularly beautiful, but our apartment in it is comfortable. In the summer, the island feels very lively because many visitors come, and there are often beach parties. In winter, we mostly see the other families who live here, but there aren’t as many teenagers as I had hoped. The adults support each other and help with repairs on the island, which can be hard work.

The biggest change for me was taking a boat every day to my old school. I looked forward to the stormy days with big waves, but the ferries don’t operate then! I also learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I miss the last ferry home, which is stressful. So, when my friends come to visit, I always tell them to hurry! But we often enjoy amazing views, especially when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, it’s so foggy that you can’t see anything, but then it can suddenly turn into bright sunshine, which still surprises me even after living here for a while.

Of course, we do experience terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to withstand them. But then I remind myself that it has been here for centuries and is still standing strong!

I live in a house in the beautiful countryside of Scotland. I have always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby: birdwatching! I went to the mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural habitat. I spent hours observing them with my parents, who taught me how to identify different species and find the best spots to see them. It was incredible, and when we returned home, I joined a local birdwatchers’ club for young people. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I am close to achieving it. During family holidays abroad, I have seen birds from other countries as well. We always look for places that offer group birdwatching activities so I can add new birds to my list! 

I have been to Egypt, and last summer we traveled to South America, where I thought I might see my 200th species. I wasn’t too disappointed when it didn’t happen, as I have learned that patience is important in this hobby. I shared a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers found it interesting and commented positively. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I felt nervous just before I went on stage, knowing that the whole school and my friends were watching me. I had notes to help me, and I remembered what to say. I only relaxed after it was over when the teachers told me I had prepared well and that they enjoyed it. I might even do another presentation next year!

I feel fortunate to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not consider birdwatching, but there are actually many birds to see, especially in areas with lots of greenery. I believe birdwatching clubs should work to attract more young people to this hobby. Everyone should connect with nature, no matter their age, and it doesn’t have to be expensive.

I began playing football when I was 7 years old. I would hurry home from school to play with other kids. I loved the game, and soon I became a decent player. My family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought I would do the same with football. But that never happened. I even started dreaming of becoming a professional football player as I grew older. 

The chance to pursue this dream came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one of the referees saw my potential and asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. After that, she invited me to join her team. At first, I couldn’t believe it—I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But the manager was impressed, and at just 13 years old, I began regular training with a big club. I improved a lot during this time.

Despite my progress, some people doubted I would ever become a star player, which made me feel a bit sad. However, my coach encouraged me to be myself and to believe in my abilities. He even let me play in one of the club’s championship matches earlier than I expected! I ran harder than ever because I didn’t want to let my teammates down. By chance, I scored the winning goal. Even with a large crowd, I could hear my coach cheering for me, and after the match, my teammates carried me around the pitch. It was amazing! Since then, I have scored many more winning goals.

Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and give them a chance to meet other players from my club. This will help them see what a professional environment is like and inspire them to believe they could play for a top team if they are willing to work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach gave me: there will be good times, but also some challenges. Fortunately, I have faced very few challenges, so I consider myself lucky!

One of the most interesting changes in education in the UK and around the world in recent years is the push for new students to get involved in research as soon as they start their studies. This change acknowledges that research is not just for famous scholars at old universities or scientists making new discoveries. Instead, research is a natural and essential way to build knowledge and skills. The skills you learn from research will be valuable not only in your studies but also in your future jobs, as they help you think critically about the world and approach your work effectively.

As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just memorize and repeat information; you create it. Creating knowledge involves asking questions rather than accepting things as they are. You might wonder: Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? How does it work in this situation? What should we think about the facts, opinions, or beliefs we encounter? Why is this important? These questions are at the heart of what we call research.

Research can be seen as a range of activities. On one end, there is complex, groundbreaking research done by highly trained experts, which leads to significant changes and new knowledge. However, research can also start from simple inquiries that involve careful work, thoughtful questions about various issues, following leads, and making practical suggestions.

Most students have always been researchers in some way. You have likely done some research for school projects or answered questions at work since you began your education. You have asked questions that required investigation, whether you were curious about studying or figuring out how to do everyday tasks, like planning a holiday, growing plants, fixing things at home, training a pet, or shopping online.

In college and higher education, you are expected to have an inquisitive mind, identify problems and questions, critically evaluate information and ideas, and create your own responses and knowledge to contribute to discussions. Some students may find this challenging because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as fixed, and learning often involves listening to teachers and texts without questioning them. It may feel disrespectful to challenge established knowledge or authority, and you might think you should be told what is important to learn.

However, in higher education in the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged. Engaging with and constructing knowledge can seem intimidating, but critical thinking is crucial in research. The research done by others is valuable for students, academics, and professionals, but we must not simply repeat what we read or accept everything as fact. Instead, we should think critically about it, test it, and determine whether the information is logical, well-reasoned, and supported by evidence. We should avoid relying blindly on the facts and information provided by others.

Cities have always been centers of intellectual activity. In the 18th century, coffee houses in London were places where people discussed science and politics. Similarly, in modern Paris, cafés on the Left Bank were popular among artists like Pablo Picasso, who talked about modern art. However, living in a city can be challenging. The same London cafés that encouraged discussion also contributed to the spread of diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. 

Today, cities are known for their creativity, but they can also feel overwhelming and unnatural. Recent scientific studies have started to explore how city life impacts our brains, and the findings are concerning. While it has long been understood that city living can be tiring, new research indicates that it can actually impair our thinking, sometimes significantly. One major factor is the lack of nature in urban environments. Research shows that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even brief views of nature can enhance brain function by providing a mental break from the stress of city life.

This research comes at a significant time: for the first time in history, more people live in cities than in rural areas. Instead of enjoying open spaces, we find ourselves in crowded concrete environments, surrounded by many strangers. It has become clear that these unnatural settings can greatly affect our mental and physical health and change the way we think. 

Consider what your brain has to manage while walking down a busy street: distracted people, dangerous road crossings, and the complex layout of the city. These everyday tasks can drain our mental energy because they require us to constantly shift our focus. The brain is like a powerful computer, but paying attention uses a lot of its energy. In contrast, natural environments do not demand as much mental effort. This concept is known as attention restoration theory, introduced by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He suggested that being in nature can help restore our attention. Natural settings have elements that naturally attract our focus without causing stress, unlike loud noises like police sirens. This allows our mental resources to recover.

Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the negative effects of city life and sought ways to incorporate nature into urban areas. Parks, like Central Park in New York, provide a much-needed escape from city life. A well-designed park can enhance brain function in just a few minutes. While many have looked for ways to boost mental performance, such as energy drinks or office redesigns, nothing seems to be as effective as simply walking in nature.

Given the many mental challenges caused by city living, one might wonder why cities keep growing. Even in our digital age, cities remain vibrant centers of intellectual activity. Research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same urban features that can lead to attention and memory problems—like crowded streets—are also linked to innovation. Scientists believe that the “concentration of social interactions” is key to urban creativity. Just as the crowded streets of 18th-century London led to new ideas, the busy environment of 21st-century Cambridge, Massachusetts, fosters creativity in technology. Conversely, less crowded areas may produce less innovation over time.

The challenge, then, is to find ways to reduce the negative psychological effects of city life while preserving its unique advantages. After all, there will always be moments when someone might say, “I’m tired of nature; take me to the city!”

Where should we search for the mind? This question may seem strange because we usually think that thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging techniques that support this idea. However, I believe there is no strong reason to limit the study of the mind to just the brain or the body. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, showing that objects, as well as brain cells, play a role in how we think. 

From an archaeological perspective, it is clear that items like stone tools, jewelry, carvings, clay tokens, and writing systems have significantly influenced human evolution and the development of our minds. Therefore, I propose that what exists outside our heads may also be part of our minds. 

It is understandable why we often connect the mind with the brain. Most of our knowledge about the mind comes from studying people in isolation from their surroundings. This approach is practical for neuroscientists, especially when using brain scanners. However, it often overlooks the fact that much of our thinking occurs outside our heads. I do not intend to deny the importance of the brain in thinking, but I want to emphasize that the mind is more than just the brain. 

Instead, we should consider the idea that human intelligence extends beyond our bodies into culture and the material world. This is where my new theory, called Material Engagement Theory (MET), comes into play. MET explores how objects can become extensions of our thinking or be integrated into our bodies. For example, when we create numbers and symbols from clay or use a stone to make a tool, we are engaging with materials in a cognitive way. 

MET also looks at how these interactions have changed since ancient times and what these changes mean for our thinking. This perspective provides new insights into what minds are and how they function by examining the role of objects in our thinking. 

Consider a blind person using a stick. Where does this person's self begin? The connection between the blind person and the stick illustrates how minds and objects can be seen as interconnected. It also highlights the flexibility of the human mind: by using the stick, the blind person transforms touch into a form of sight, and the stick itself plays an active role. The brain perceives the stick as part of the body. 

The blind person’s stick reminds us that human intelligence can adapt and change significantly by incorporating new technologies. I view the human mind as an ongoing project, constantly evolving. It is essential to remember that, regardless of the form that tools have taken throughout our history—from ancient stone tools to modern technology—their main purpose has been to connect us with our environment rather than to limit us. 

For humans, tools are used to satisfy our curiosity and desire for knowledge. This unique ability to engage with material culture explains why humans create more than any other species, and how these creations shape our minds. I refer to this concept as metaplasticity—our minds are flexible and develop as we interact with the material world. 

I aim to reintroduce the importance of materiality in understanding cognition. MET provides a new perspective on how various forms of material culture, from ancient tools to smartphones, have played a crucial role in defining and transforming who we are and how we think. While the idea of technology changing our minds may sound futuristic, it is important to recognize that humans have been using such technology since our earliest days.

Few inventions have changed civilization as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of culture at all levels—practical, scientific, industrial, and artistic. It also opened up new forms of entertainment. Historians argue that photography is the greatest contribution of the US to the visual arts, as it has become central to American intellectual and artistic discussions. To fully appreciate its impact, we need to look at its origins in the mid-19th century.

Photography was appealing for several reasons. First, it was a mechanical process that matched the growing interest in technology, reflecting a national attitude that embraced change. Just as steam power, railroads, and electricity made communication and travel easier, photography brought the wonders of the world into homes in an immediate way. 

Second, the camera became the preferred tool for expressing identity, allowing people to create images for public viewing in a society that constantly reinvented individual and national identities. Third, the camera played a significant role in preserving family memories, even if those memories were somewhat idealized. Finally, the realism of photographs aligned with a broader artistic trend towards depicting everyday life in US art.

Every photograph draws attention to something specific, showing what the photographer wants us to see. Because photographs are created by machines, they are records of events, people, and objects, which gives them a sense of objectivity. However, since each photograph is taken by a person, it also carries a subjective viewpoint. We might think we understand a photograph because we recognize its subject, leading to the idea that photography is a "universal language." Yet, the meaning of a photograph is more complex. 

No subject inherently conveys its own meaning, and every image is presented with some context that shapes our understanding—like a caption in a newspaper or its placement in a gallery. To understand a photograph historically, we must consider its purpose and context: Why did the photographer take it? How was it first seen? Additionally, the same image can have different meanings depending on where and when it is viewed.

While the importance of the camera to artists was not widely recognized for a long time, it is now clear. In recent decades, starting with artist Andy Warhol's use of photographs in his work, many artists have incorporated photography in various ways. In summary, photography has become an essential part of art, complementing painting and shaping our ideas of representation before the camera was invented.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and physician known as one of the founders of modern psychology, defined psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still relevant today. We all have a mental life, which gives us some understanding of the concept, but it can be difficult to study, not just in humans but also in animals like rats and monkeys. James focused on human psychology, which he believed included basic elements: thoughts, feelings, a physical world that exists in time and space, and a way of knowing about these elements. Our knowledge is mostly personal and comes from our own thoughts, feelings, and experiences, which may or may not align with scientific facts. 

This personal understanding can lead us to make judgments about psychological issues based on our own experiences. We often act as amateur psychologists when we share opinions on complex topics, such as whether brainwashing is effective or why people behave in certain ways, like feeling insulted or unhappy. Problems can arise when two people interpret situations differently. Formal psychology aims to provide methods to determine which explanations are most likely correct in specific situations. Psychologists help us differentiate between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and objective facts.

While psychology studies the mind and brain, psychologists do not yet fully understand how the brain works in relation to our emotions and behaviors, such as during childbirth or watching a football game. It is often not possible to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by observing behavior and forming hypotheses about what happens inside us. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective and verifiable, but the mind's workings are not directly observable like a machine's. Instead, we can only infer them from behavior.

Studying psychology is similar to solving a crossword puzzle; it requires evaluating and interpreting clues. These clues must come from careful observation, accurate measurement, and logical analysis that can be publicly examined. Psychology often involves complex interactions, and understanding these requires advanced techniques and theories. Like any other science, psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and learn how to influence the processes it studies. Achieving these goals can help us understand our experiences and apply findings to improve people's lives.

Psychological research has been beneficial in various areas, such as creating better methods for teaching children to read, designing safer machine control panels, and helping emotionally distressed individuals communicate their feelings. Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, scientific investigation has only occurred in the last 150 years. Early psychologists used introspection, or self-reflection, to answer psychological questions, focusing on identifying mental structures. While this remains an interest today, introspection has clear limitations. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it only allows us to see a small part of the brain's automatic functions. William James compared introspection to trying to see how darkness looks by turning up the gas quickly. Therefore, modern psychologists prefer to base their theories on careful observations of others' behavior rather than solely on their own experiences.

In a simple building in a regular business park in Michigan, USA, there is a unique collection known as the Museum of Failed Products. This museum, owned by a company called GfK, displays items that were taken off the market because very few people wanted to buy them. The owner, Carol Sherry, believes that each product tells a story about the designers, marketers, and salespeople involved. 

What is surprising is that this museum exists as a successful business. You might think that any serious manufacturer would keep a collection of their failed products, but many executives who visit the museum show that this is not common. They often avoid thinking about their failures and do not keep samples of their unsuccessful products. 

The museum was started by Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, who originally wanted to create a library of consumer products, not just failed ones. Beginning in the 1960s, he collected samples of every new product he could find. He did not realize that most products fail, which led to his collection being mostly made up of unsuccessful items. 

Today’s optimistic culture likely contributes to the products in the museum. Each product probably went through many meetings where people did not see the problems. Even if they did, marketers might have felt pressured to invest more money in a failing product to save face. Little effort is made to understand why these products failed, and people often avoid discussing it.

This focus on positivity is especially strong in the self-help industry, where a common idea is "positive visualization." This means that if you imagine things going well, they are more likely to happen. Some researchers, like neuroscientist Tali Sharot, suggest that our brains may be wired to see the chances of success as higher than they really are. Her research indicates that well-adjusted people often have an overly optimistic view of their ability to influence outcomes, unlike those who are depressed.

However, how effective are these positive thoughts about the future? Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen and her team have studied this question. Their findings show that spending time imagining success can actually reduce people's motivation to reach their goals. For instance, people who were encouraged to think about having a very successful week at work ended up achieving less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck explains that our experiences with failure depend on our beliefs about ability. People with a "fixed mindset" believe that ability is something you are born with, while those with a "growth mindset" think it can develop through effort and challenges. Those with a fixed mindset find failure very upsetting because it suggests they did not meet expectations. For example, a talented athlete who believes they are naturally gifted may not practice enough to reach their potential. In contrast, people with a growth mindset see failure as a sign that they are pushing their limits. Dweck compares this to weight training, where muscles grow stronger by being challenged. Overall, having a growth mindset is a more positive way to approach life, regardless of whether it leads to success.

Text: 'Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But do we really understand why? It seems obvious, but professional sports are changing quickly, and many things we thought were true are now being questioned. Two main factors are challenging the idea of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists want to discover what helps players perform their best, leading to many theories about home advantage. At the same time, those who invest in sports want to know why home advantage is still important. If players are paid well, shouldn’t they feel comfortable playing anywhere?

This raises questions for fans. For example, would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their team needs their support and loyalty. This belief may lead them to confuse cause and effect. When a team plays well, the home crowd cheers loudly, and sometimes this leads to a goal. Fans often remember the cheering and the goal, but they forget the many times the cheering didn’t lead to success.

However, there is one common belief among fans that scientific evidence supports. Home fans not only cheer for their team but also direct a lot of their noise at the referee. In a well-known study, referees watched a match with crowd noise and another version without sound. The referees who heard the crowd were less likely to call fouls against the home team compared to those who watched in silence. Interestingly, the crowd noise did not make them more likely to call fouls against the away team. The researchers concluded that referees try to avoid the stress of making calls that would upset the home crowd.

Recent studies show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the early years of the Football League in the 1890s, home teams won about 70% of the points, while today they win about 60%. One reason for this change could be travel. In the past, travel was difficult, but now players travel in comfort, and if their hotel isn’t good enough, the club will find them a better one. Local conditions used to vary greatly, but now top stadiums are becoming more similar in their efficiency.

Despite these explanations, none fully explains the data. These changes, like pampered players and similar stadiums, have happened recently. The mystery remains why home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the highest home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. One reason could be that home advantage is more about teamwork, and baseball focuses more on individual matchups between the batter and pitcher. Team sports require coordination among teammates. In basketball, success depends on teamwork, which builds confidence when playing at home, regardless of the playing conditions.

Another possibility relates to a more primal aspect of sports. Research shows that players’ testosterone levels are normal before training and away games, but can be 67% higher before home games. This increase may be linked to a natural instinct to protect their home ground. For example, during the Rugby World Cup, underdog teams playing at home won against stronger opponents, showing determination and aggression—characteristics of home advantage. As one referee put it, ‘It’s the law of the jungle out there.’'

"The more I practice, the luckier I get," said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying has become famous among dedicated athletes and their coaches. The quote's origin is debated, with many claiming it was said by other golfers of that time. Its meaning is also unclear. Player was not talking about luck in a literal sense; he was being ironic. His real message was that more practice leads to better performance, but only up to a certain point. 

This idea connects to the nature-nurture debate, which questions whether talent is something we are born with or something we develop. However, this discussion is not balanced; it often favors the idea that practice is more important than natural talent. Psychologist Anders Ericsson is known for the theory that becoming an expert in any field requires 10,000 hours of practice. This idea has been popularized in books like Malcolm Gladwell's "Outliers," as well as "Talent Is Overrated" and "Bounce: The Myth of Talent and the Power of Practice." These books generally agree that practice is the most important factor in achieving expertise.

However, in his engaging book, Epstein challenges this view. He points out a flaw in much of the research on excellence: it often focuses only on successful individuals. He asks if there are better ways to understand why some people have certain abilities while others do not, and how to separate innate talent from factors like environment, support, and determination. 

Epstein travels around the world, from Kenya to Sweden and the Arctic, to find answers. In Alaska, he discovers that the drive and desire of sled dogs in a tough race may be influenced by their genetics, suggesting a link between nature and traits we think are voluntary. This raises the question: can determination be a choice, or is it partly genetic?

Epstein emphasizes the complexity of this topic. He distinguishes between "hardware" (nature) and "software" (nurture), agreeing that both are essential for elite athletes. He does not deny the importance of training and environment, suggesting that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a good basketball player instead of the fastest man in history. 

Epstein also explores the roles of race and gender in sports. He questions why we separate men and women in competitions if only practice matters. Sometimes, the best questions are the most straightforward.

A recent international report shows that many children in wealthy countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks a simple question: why are today’s children so dissatisfied? In her new book, Kith, she explains that these children spend too much time indoors, stuck in front of screens, and have lost touch with nature – the woods, mountains, rivers, and streams. She believes this is the main issue. 

A follow-up study interviewed children to understand their feelings better. It found that many of them do not wish for the latest technology; instead, they would be happier if they could spend more time outside. Many adults over 40 often reminisce about their own childhoods, recalling how they enjoyed long summer days exploring, swimming, or building forts. They argue that this was healthier than the protected lives of today’s children. However, they often forget that they are the ones who created this protective environment for their kids, avoiding risks like building forts in old sheds.

Griffiths’ book contains strong arguments. She discusses how the fear of dangers in the outside world leads parents to keep their children at home, which benefits the toy and gadget industry that sells entertainment for indoor kids. She also criticizes trends like prescribing medication for restless children or requiring safety goggles for playground games. While I am unsure how common these strict rules are, Griffiths expresses her frustration with passion, discussing various aspects of childhood freedoms and limitations, from fairy tales to school rules.

However, Griffiths sometimes goes too far with her ideas and ignores important counterarguments. At one point, she even compares the modern treatment of children to a subtle form of racism, which seems extreme. She tends to have a romantic view of children, often overlooking their more challenging behaviors. For example, she claims that “children are the musicians of thought,” suggesting they could be creative if given the chance, but I doubt this is always true.

One of the main themes of the book is that children should have the freedom to explore and take risks. Griffiths argues that children need to experience some danger to learn how to manage risks. She writes, “Children need accidents,” meaning small accidents that help them avoid bigger ones later. However, she does not explain how to create these small accidents safely. Additionally, not all children may want the adventurous lifestyle Griffiths admires. What about those who are naturally shy or prefer staying at home? Perhaps the real issue is that we try to fit all children into the same mold, whether by keeping them indoors or pushing them outside.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, which means I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and personal life, but this skill is not just about what I learned in school. Many life problems cannot be solved with complicated formulas or memorized answers from school. Instead, they need judgment, wisdom, and creativity that come from real-life experiences. For children, these experiences often happen through play. 

My recent research focuses on how important play is for children's development. All young mammals, including humans, play, and those who have the most to learn tend to play the most. Carnivores, like lions, play more than herbivores, like cows, because hunting is more complex than grazing. Primates, including humans, play more than other mammals because they rely more on learning than on instinct. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they are given the chance. 

Play is a natural way for both adults and young mammals to learn. The most important skills children need to live happy and productive lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced through play. They include thinking creatively, getting along with others, cooperating, and managing their own feelings. Creativity is essential for success in today’s economy. We no longer need people who simply follow instructions or perform routine tasks. Instead, we need individuals who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can encourage creative thinkers, we will have a strong workforce. 

However, creativity cannot be directly taught; it can be stifled by a school system that focuses on fixed questions and answers. More importantly, children need to learn how to interact with others, care for them, and work together. Children naturally want to play with each other, and through play, they develop social skills and learn about fairness and morality, which are crucial for their future. 

Play is voluntary, meaning players can choose to stop at any time. If they cannot quit, it is not truly play. Players understand that to keep the game enjoyable, they must consider the happiness of others. This freedom makes play a very democratic activity. 

Unfortunately, school has become more demanding, with fewer breaks, more homework, and greater pressure for high grades. Outside of school, organized sports have taken the place of spontaneous games, and adult-supervised playdates have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play. Adults often feel they need to step in rather than allowing children to resolve their own conflicts. 

These changes have happened slowly but have had a significant impact over time. They are influenced by various social factors, such as parents' fears, warnings from experts about dangers, less connected neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. 

Our children do not need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change the negative trend of the past fifty years. We need to give childhood back to children, allowing them to play and explore so they can grow into strong, well-rounded adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more young people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn allow them to connect directly with potential employers, which is much easier than the old method of standing outside an office with a sign saying "hire me." However, this increased access also means there is a higher risk of making mistakes.

For example, a young job seeker in the US reached out to a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. This executive had many influential contacts, and the job seeker thought she might help him. However, the executive was offended by the idea of sharing her contacts with a stranger who hadn’t earned that privilege. She not only rejected his request but also sent a sarcastic message that quickly spread online. Many people were shocked by her response, and she likely regrets her tone, if not her message. 

This incident highlights an important point: social media can be a risky tool for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly. Unfortunately, many young people are making mistakes. There is an irony here because social networking sites like Facebook and Twitter have been central to the social lives of young people for years. When older generations were teenagers, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers, a place to impress others and create a different identity. 

However, using social media for professional networking is very different, and some young people do not see this difference. They may still act boldly and confidently, thinking this is appropriate. Just because many people liked your posts on Facebook does not mean you can use LinkedIn to show employers you are a good candidate. It is important to understand that the social networking skills learned as teenagers do not apply in the professional world. 

Employers often complain that young job seekers are too casual in their communication and come across as arrogant. This reinforces the stereotype of young people as an "entitled generation." In reality, many young people are struggling to find jobs, which is why they are using social media. This perception of arrogance can hurt their chances, even if they have the skills and motivation to be valuable employees.

So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly introduce yourself and explain what you can offer them, such as doing research or helping in another way. This approach increases your chances of receiving a positive response. Avoid sending generic messages, and keep your tone respectful to leave a good impression. Remember, social media can be a powerful tool for making connections, but it requires careful use to avoid closing doors.

Anyone who claims they can accurately predict the future of newspapers is either lying or mistaken. The numbers show a troubling trend: since 2000, the circulation of most UK national newspapers has dropped by 30 to 50 percent. According to the Pew Research Centre in the USA, only 26 percent of Americans now rely on newspapers for news, down from 45 percent in 2001. Many people confidently predict that printed newspapers will disappear within 15 years. However, history shows that traditional media often survive longer than expected. 

For example, in 1835, a journalist in New York claimed that books and theatre were finished, and that newspapers would become the main source of social life. Yet theatre has survived alongside newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has thrived even in the age of TV, and cinema has continued to do well despite the rise of videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have made a comeback, with online sales increasing by 745 percent since 2008. 

Interestingly, newspapers were once considered a new form of media. It took centuries for them to become the primary source of news, which was made possible by advancements like the steam press, railways, and the telegraph in the mid-19th century. This shift also involved a new understanding that the world is constantly changing, and we need regular updates—an idea that was foreign in medieval times. Back then, people mainly recognized the changing seasons and unexpected disasters like famine or disease. Life was seen as cyclical, with recurring truths.
