Before the 19th century, journalism as a profession was not well established, and there was little reason for most people to seek news regularly. The fixed schedule and format of newspapers can be limiting. In contrast, online news allows readers to access information based on their own interests and the urgency of events. Advanced search engines and algorithms help personalize news, and updates can be made almost instantly when important stories break. There are no space limits, allowing for more detailed narratives and analyses.

However, many news providers seem focused on being the first to report rather than on spreading understanding. This creates confusion, similar to the medieval marketplace where news was mixed with rumors and misunderstandings. Newspapers have often struggled to explain how the world works. They may be facing extinction, or perhaps, as the internet adds to our sense of living in a chaotic universe, newspapers might find a way to guide us toward greater wisdom and understanding.

If humans truly felt comfortable under the moon and stars, we would walk in the dark happily, just like many nocturnal animals that thrive in it. However, we are daytime creatures, with eyes designed for sunlight. This fact is deeply rooted in our genetics, even if we don’t often think of ourselves as daytime beings, just as we don’t think of ourselves as primates or mammals. This understanding helps explain our impact on the night. We have changed the night by filling it with artificial light. This control is similar to building a dam on a river. While it has benefits, it also leads to light pollution, which scientists are just starting to study. 

Light pollution mainly comes from poor lighting design that allows artificial light to shine into the sky instead of focusing it downward where it is needed. Bad lighting brightens the night, changing the light levels and rhythms that many life forms, including humans, have adapted to. Wherever artificial light spreads into nature, it affects various life activities like migration, reproduction, and feeding. 

For most of human history, the term ‘light pollution’ would have been meaningless. Imagine walking towards London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the most populated city on Earth. Nearly a million people lived there, using candles, torches, and lanterns. Only a few homes had gas lighting, and there were no public gaslights in the streets for another seven years. From a distance, you would have been more likely to smell London than to see its faint glow. We have illuminated the night as if it were empty, but that is far from the truth. There are many nocturnal species among mammals. Light is a strong biological force that attracts many species. Scientists have noted that songbirds and seabirds can be ‘captured’ by searchlights or gas flares, circling endlessly until they fall. Birds that migrate at night often crash into brightly lit tall buildings, and young birds on their first journeys are especially affected. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at odd hours due to artificial light.

Initially, it was believed that light pollution only impacted astronomers, who need to see the night sky clearly. While most of us may not require a perfect view of the night sky for our work, we, like many other creatures, need darkness. Rejecting darkness is pointless. It is crucial for our biological well-being, just like light. Disrupting our internal clock can lead to various health issues. The regular cycle of waking and sleeping reflects the natural light changes on Earth. These rhythms are so essential to our existence that disturbing them is like changing our center of gravity. 

In the end, humans are just as affected by light pollution as frogs living near a brightly lit highway. By living in our own artificial light, we have disconnected ourselves from our evolutionary and cultural roots—the light of the stars and the natural rhythms of day and night. Light pollution makes us forget our true place in the universe and the vastness of our existence, which is best understood against the backdrop of a dark night filled with the Milky Way overhead.

The founder of a large multinational company recently announced that his business will stop tracking employees' paid holiday time. This decision seems to be inspired by a similar policy from an internet company. The founder mentioned that he got the idea from a cheerful email from his daughter, which many newspapers have shared. However, this way of announcing the change feels like a superficial attempt to make a potentially unkind policy seem more friendly. 

We should consider whether this idea is practical. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational has 50,000 employees and many different services, including finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want, as long as it doesn't hurt the business" seems more suitable for a smaller company where employees know each other's workloads better. In a larger company, it is harder to judge whether taking time off will negatively impact the business or their careers.

The founder has said that employees can take as much leave as they want, as long as they feel completely sure that their team is up to date on all projects and that their absence won't harm the business. But is it really possible to be that certain? No matter how much work you finish before a holiday, there will always be more waiting for you when you return. This means that employees might feel guilty about taking time off, which can lead to stress. If workers feel pressured not to take leave, it could actually reduce productivity over time.

Additionally, there may be pressure from colleagues and office gossip about who is taking time off and for how long. In many corporate environments, there is a culture of working late, which could lead to a situation where employees feel they cannot take holidays, especially if they are competing for promotions. Without the security of guaranteed leave, employees might hesitate to take the time they need, fearing they will seem lazy. 

This policy could create a situation where workers feel stuck and unable to take their entitled leave, or they might continue to rely on their legal rights as a guideline, making the new policy ineffective. Modern technology has also blurred the lines between work and personal time, as employees can receive work messages anytime and anywhere. 

The internet company started its unlimited leave policy because employees wanted to know how it fit with the old system of tracking time off. If the company can’t keep track of how much time employees work, why should it apply a different standard for time off? However, a downside of having no set working hours is that employees may feel they are always being watched, which can lead to unhealthy self-discipline.

Employment laws exist for a reason. Workers have a right to a minimum amount of paid leave because rest is essential for their mental and physical health. The benefits of increased morale, creativity, and productivity can happen without compromising worker well-being. Therefore, I am skeptical that allowing employees to take as much holiday as they want is truly the goal or will be the result of this policy.

Journal-based peer review is the process where experts in a field evaluate a scientific research paper before it is published. This process is often seen as a way to ensure the quality of research, as it aims to prevent flawed or nonsensical papers from being published. However, reviewing a paper can delay its publication by up to a year, raising the question of whether this delay is worth it for the reliability of published research. The answer is both yes and no, and exploring this issue reveals much about the current state of scientific publishing, which is changing.

I still believe in the importance of journal-based peer review and think that all papers should go through some form of checking before they are published. However, I notice a shift happening. The increasing use of preprints—drafts of papers shared online without peer review—plays a significant role in this change. Preprints allow researchers to quickly share new findings so that others can read, critique, and build upon them. The focus of journal publication has shifted more towards reputation and career advancement, which has affected both authors' motivations and reviewers' roles.

The competition for publication in prestigious journals encourages scientists to produce high-quality work, and these journals do publish excellent research. However, the strong rewards for publishing in top journals can lead to shortcuts, as researchers may omit inconvenient data to make their work more appealing. Reviewers are often tasked with deciding if a paper is good enough for a journal rather than assessing its overall quality. For leading journals, this decision can depend more on the paper's relevance or newsworthiness than on its scientific merit.

These issues are well recognized, but many are reluctant to change the current system. However, as biologist Ron Vale recently suggested in a preprint, preprints could offer a solution without drastically changing the existing norms. Although preprint archives have existed for twenty years, they have not been widely adopted. This slow acceptance reflects scientists' conservative nature and the common belief that journals will not accept papers that have been shared as preprints. There is also concern that publishing papers without peer review could lead to the spread of poor-quality research, although this has not yet happened.

While preprints are not peer-reviewed, authors understand that they are open to critique and discussion from a global community of reviewers. For example, psychology professor Tanya Elks shared her experience of critiquing a published paper. In the traditional peer review system, the original authors might block critical feedback, or if they are not chosen as reviewers, they could complain about misrepresentation. By posting a preprint, both sides could engage in open discussion, allowing readers to assess the quality of the arguments. The risk of rejection by journals is less concerning since the preprint and its comments remain publicly available, ensuring that the work is not wasted.

Preprint archives facilitate informal scientific discussions that were once limited to private correspondence. They can also serve as a platform for sharing negative results, which are often overlooked by journals focused on new discoveries. Additionally, being on preprint archives significantly increases the visibility and citation of papers, demonstrating the effectiveness of this method of sharing research. By embracing the internet's culture of openness and collaboration, preprints can help shift the focus back to the quality of the research itself, rather than the prestige of the publication.

When I ask my literature students to define a poem, they often say it is "a painting in words." However, these answers usually do not satisfy either me or them. One day, I asked a group of students to choose an object and write two paragraphs about it: one as a scientist would, describing it objectively, and another from the object's perspective, titled "Poem." One student wrote about an oxygen mask, saying, "I may look weird or terrifying, but I’m a device that helps people breathe." This unusual choice helped the class understand how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise led to laughter and meaningful discussions.

When I was in school, I found poetry confusing. I viewed each poem as a puzzling challenge that hindered true understanding and emotion. After school, many people become less interested in poetry. Occasionally, a poem catches your attention because it is not continuous prose. It challenges you to read it, but often you feel let down by its simplicity or because you don’t understand it at first. Still, you feel proud for trying.

What do we seek in poems? We might expect them to express deep emotions, beautiful images, thoughtful reflections, or sharp humor. While this seems true, we often turn to films for tears, online articles for information, novels for escape, and music for a perfect blend of lyrics and melody. However, one unique aspect of poetry is its ambiguity, which reflects the complexities of everyday life.

Searching online for "poem" leads to "poetry," defined as a form of literary art that uses the beauty and rhythm of language. This definition sounds impressive, but it overlooks the word's origins. "Poem" comes from the Greek word poí?ma, meaning "a thing made," and a poet is a "maker of things." So, if a poem is a created thing, what kind of thing is it? Some poets compare poems to wild animals—uncontrollable and unpredictable—or to machines—carefully designed and precise. However, these comparisons often break down upon closer examination.

The most valuable part of trying to define a poem through comparison is the discussion it generates. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this debate can change how you think about both. It encourages us to rethink our usual patterns of thought and see ordinary things in a new way. Poems can be mental objects, especially since song lyrics often stick in our minds. The combination of words and melody has a strong impact, similar to schoolyard rhymes like "Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me." Yet, words can sometimes hurt, just like sticks and stones.

Consider a poem printed in a newspaper or magazine. It can resonate deeply, even though it is just ink on paper, like the prose surrounding it. The white space around the poem could have been used for a longer article or an ad. A poem is crafted through writing and rewriting, just like any article or story, but it does not aim to be a product for sale. Publishers promote poetry collections, but few expect them to be profitable. A poem exists for its own sake, and because of its unique position in a magazine or book, it can still surprise us, even if just for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector shortly after getting married. At that time, £70 was a lot of money, and I could have used it for something practical for our home. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first outing. Over the years, every brooch and coin I discovered brought me joy because it made me feel connected to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years before I found something that impressed Marion again.

One dull February afternoon, I had a couple of hours free and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a nearby spot known for old farming equipment. When my detector first beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I tried to ignore it, but I couldn’t walk away without checking. I dug down about half a meter and lay in the mud when I saw a rounded, golden ball. Having found brass curtain rails before, I tried not to get my hopes up. But as I cleared more dirt, the ball turned into a thick, beautifully designed loop. I stopped and stared, remembering to breathe. I had seen something like this before—the Great Torc, which is displayed in the British Museum. It’s a famous piece from Iron Age Britain, over 2,000 years old. A torc is a twisted necklace made of gold and silver, with gold rings at each end, just like the one I had found.

I took it to my car and couldn’t stop looking at it on the passenger seat during the drive home. I rinsed it in my kitchen sink, probably the first clean it had in centuries. “Marion!” I called out, “I have something for you.” As I admired my find, I heard my wife enter the room and pause. “What is it?” she asked after a moment. I told her it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn’t try it on because we were worried about damaging it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe. Although we had never been robbed, I felt anxious and restless. Eventually, I got up, unscrewed a floorboard in my office, and hid it underneath.

The law requires that such discoveries be reported to the authorities within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc as much as I could before handing it over. I even took it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I brought it to the council office in the same bag. The registrar was talking to someone with his back to me. When I placed the torc on his desk, he turned around, stopped mid-sentence, and authenticated it. Eventually, it was sold to my local council and is now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 from the sale was shared between the landowner and me. 

However, the torc means more to me than just a lucky find. I feel like I have preserved a piece of history for the nation. People often say to me, “Now that you’ve made such a great discovery, will you stop detecting?” But I still find brooches and coins just as interesting. Besides, if a fisherman catches a big fish, he doesn’t stop fishing—there’s always the chance of catching an even bigger one tomorrow.

Sleeping is one of my greatest joys when I travel, but I rarely mention it because I feel a bit guilty. When my friends talk about their carefully planned trips filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and stay quiet. What would they think if they knew my travel plans often include long naps during afternoon rainstorms and lazy mornings in comfortable beds in Italy? Better sleep is one of the nice benefits of traveling. 

When I went to Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—over 12 hours most days. Even with noisy birds nearby, it didn’t bother me. Away from home and my own bed, surrounded by new smells and sounds, I could enjoy a deeper, more dream-filled sleep than I ever expected. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. 

However, I believe that the quality of sleep while traveling is different for a reason. I think sleep is actually part of the travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we expose ourselves to new sights, sounds, smells, and ways of living. This flood of new experiences continues even while we sleep. It makes sense that sleep feels more intense when we are away from home.

Sleep also changes in rhythm depending on where we are. People often worry about jet lag, but I think the challenges I face after long trips are more about adjusting to local cultures than just time differences. For instance, in Trinidad, people wake up early to avoid the heat, slow down around 10 a.m. when the sun is strong, and then become active again in the cool evening. Even though Trinidad is only one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to adjust to their different sleep patterns. When I finally adapt, I feel like I have truly arrived.

I remember one afternoon in Santo Domingo, the capital of the Dominican Republic, when I had a large lunch with new friends in an apartment overlooking the Caribbean Sea. After eating, we all felt sleepy, and one by one, my friends left the table to relax on hammocks and sofas. I realized why they had so many pillows around. I took a few for myself and joined them. I had heard about the Latin American tradition of the siesta, but that day, I truly experienced it. I shared not just sleep, but a piece of Dominican life.

Travel sleep has another wonderful quality: I remember it. Being away from my usual routine, I enjoy the new scents, textures, and sounds that fill my mind while I sleep. If the idea of ‘slow travel’—taking the time to enjoy each experience instead of rushing—is what defines the modern traveler, then what could be slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed about my love for sleep and tell my ambitious friends that travel sleep is, in fact, an important part of the journey.

The woman turned away from the mirror and asked, “What do you think? Be honest.” Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. “I still think this one looks best on you,” she said diplomatically. The woman wrinkled her nose and made a face that resembled a bulldog. “But it’s so boring,” she replied. “Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little beauty will help me stand out.” She patted the red and black miniature top hat on her head. “Yes, this is the one I want,” she decided. 

Mia knew she couldn’t change the woman’s mind. With a smile, she agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at the wedding. As she thought about her own daughter, Jen, who was turning thirty today, she felt excited about their family gathering. It had been a while since everyone had been together, and she looked forward to seeing Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious about the friend Jen was bringing, someone they didn’t know much about. When Jen had called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, her husband Jeff had quickly reacted. “Tattie? What kind of name is that?” he had asked. “It’s short for Tatiana,” Mia explained. “I think it’s nice.” “More like something pretentious,” Jeff replied. He didn’t like anything showy and often criticized Mia for being too polite. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat and might have even said a dustbin lid would look better on her. “The problem with you, Mia,” he often said, “is that you’re too polite for your own good.”

An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered Medlar House through the back door. Her commute from work took only forty seconds. Four years ago, when Luke, their youngest child, left home, Mia decided to convert the unused barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff had been doubtful. “Do you really think there’s a demand for hats?” he asked. Mia had listened to friends complain about finding the perfect hat for special occasions and knew there was definitely a demand. She was right. From the first day, after Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became successful. Women traveled from far away to her showroom in Little Pelham, where she provided a relaxed environment for them to try on as many hats as they needed. She encouraged customers to bring their outfits to ensure a perfect match. Recently, she had expanded her business to include handbags and costume jewelry as well.

It’s a long journey from London to Atlanta, and at his new home in America, Lawrence Okoye reflects on his incredible sports journey. He is confident but seems surprised by how far he has come, from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly starting a new career. Although he has never played American football before, Lawrence is likely to be chosen for one of the major teams in the USA. In Atlanta, he is still figuring out what his new position involves.

The idea that a 21-year-old newcomer from London could be selected for one of the biggest teams in American sports is surprising. However, Lawrence is known for proving doubters wrong. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but decided to focus on training for the discus instead, having previously played rugby. Within 20 months of starting, he became the world’s fourth-best discus thrower.

Lawrence initially came to Atlanta for warm-weather training for the discus, preparing for the world championships. When asked about his sudden interest in a potential NFL contract, he confirms, “American football was in the back of my mind, but I only decided to try it when I got to the USA.” He had thought about it while in school in London, but it seemed unrealistic then. After arriving in America, he learned about the NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had no experience, he felt confident enough to apply. 

When asked if he was nervous about competing against experienced players, he replied, “No, not at all. I don’t get nervous for many things.” Although he is not very talkative, he is sure of his abilities. His performance in various tests impressed the coaches, and he was recognized as the standout player. “I was very happy to hear that,” he admitted, showing a rare moment of pride.

However, he remains cautious. With no basic experience, how can he make it onto an NFL team? “Coaches have told me I have the right qualities. It’s all about how hard I work,” he said. Will he be relaxed while waiting to hear if he has been selected? “I will be. There’s no pressure on me. Many people say I’m definitely going to be chosen, but I’m not too worried.”

This calmness may come from his disappointing experience in the Olympic discus final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved on from that moment and takes pride in having qualified for the final with a strong last throw. “That was an amazing day,” he said. “The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sports. I can always return to it.”

After his Olympic disappointment, some speculated that he had let the experience affect him, but Lawrence chooses not to comment. The minimum salary for an NFL player is over $400,000 a year, making the financial benefits clear. So, Lawrence has shifted from rugby to athletics and now to American football. Given his many talents, wouldn’t it be better to focus on just one sport? “I understand why someone would think that,” he replied. “I’m trying to achieve something I’ve dreamed about since I was a kid. If it doesn’t work out, I can always go back to the discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought out.”

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to find it was already daylight. Looking out the window at the empty landscape below, I saw dark shades of brown and green, which reassured me that, even though it was mid-September, autumn had not yet arrived in Siberia. There were no signs of human life, just a strange mix of mountains, streams, and forests stretching to the horizon. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled sleepily at me. “Good morning, Robert,” he said, saying my name with a slow Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow, traveling to the remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining companies. His English was almost as limited as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I managed to tell him that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return home to England by bicycle. 

“But, Robert,” he argued, “there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle.” I explained that I believed there was a road, even if not many people used it anymore. “Alone?” he asked, pointing at me. “No, I will be riding with a friend named Al.” “Just one friend?” “Yes, just one,” I nodded. Sergei still looked doubtful and pointed outside, saying “Holodna” (cold). I tried to convince him with hand gestures that I had plenty of warm clothes, but I didn’t mention that I was on a tight budget for my trip. Most of my clothes and gear were bought at discounted prices. In truth, I wasn’t sure if they would be good enough, especially my large postman’s over-trousers that I had bought for £10.

It all began in a lecture hall in Scotland. That morning, the hall was filled with students slumped in their seats. Some were taking notes without much energy. The lecturer was droning on. I was thinking hard about a dilemma: Should I ask him or not? “Well, why not?” I tore a fresh sheet from my pad and wrote, “Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob.” In the row in front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He tried to read my handwriting, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath while I read, “OK.” 

It was six years later that I was going to meet Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and while I still struggled to control my classes fully, the job met many important needs for me. It was often challenging, rarely boring, and quite fulfilling, plus there were long holidays to pursue adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to visit Al. He had caught the adventure bug after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more exciting than teaching: cycle around the world. Since that first ride together, Al had taken on bigger and bigger challenges. This round-the-world bike trip was certainly his biggest yet. Sometimes he thought the ride would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him in many ways. He was having an incredible adventure, proving he could handle each new challenge, even when it seemed impossible. He was showing the skeptics who said he couldn’t do it that he could. He faced something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.

In The Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots compete by flying through a series of pylons that are between 15 and 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops while flying at speeds of up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it feels like to participate. An hour before my flight, I had to sign two forms. The first confirmed that I was healthy, and the second stated that I would empty my pockets, as small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned that I needed to stay oriented throughout the experience. I was told, “The horizon is your best friend,” and the pilot would guide me on where to look. I also promised to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.

Half an hour before the flight, I attended a safety briefing where I was instructed not to touch anything. As we began taxiing down the runway, I was nervous. My legs were up, my feet avoided the important steering pedals, and my hands stayed away from the many switches nearby. Despite the instructions, I found it hard to relax and enjoy the flight. This is the challenge of high-speed acrobatic flying: to survive without fainting, you must stay calm and focused, tensing and relaxing at the right moments. Panicking is not a good idea.

As we accelerated down the runway, I felt anxious. Dario, the pilot, and I were in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes in the world. The plane took off, and just two seconds later, we made a sharp right turn. It was a sudden and intense movement that took my breath away. I looked at the horizon, tensed my body, and gasped as I sank into my seat. For a brief moment, I felt 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out, turned sharply left, and dove down, leaving my stomach behind at 2,000 meters.

Seconds later, we were just 10 meters off the ground, aiming for a narrow space between two pylons. We passed them at 400 km per hour, but my excitement was interrupted by another sharp turn. I was allowed to fly the plane for two minutes, but my hand shook so much that the plane shook too. It was very responsive. When Dario spoke to me, I asked him to repeat himself, but instead, he performed a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. “Are you okay?” he asked. “Yes,” I replied. “Have you had enough?” “No,” I lied. Then he did a loop, flying up and over in a full circle. 

I know many people would find this thrilling, like those who enjoy roller coasters. However, I thought it was overwhelming. At the top of the loop, while upside down, I heard a voice saying, “Relax, relax, look up.” I looked up and saw fields below. The flight lasted only 10 minutes, but it felt much softer compared to what the pilots experience during races. To show how relaxed he was, Dario pulled out sandwiches as soon as we landed and happily started eating. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I kept dreaming about the loop over and over again.

Doug Allan is a filmmaker who captures wild animals in cold environments. If you have seen impressive videos of polar bears in nature documentaries, they were likely filmed by him. He prefers working in temperatures around -18°C. Allan originally trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver, which helped him learn how to survive in cold conditions. His big opportunity came when a TV crew visited Antarctica, where he was working, to make a wildlife documentary. He ended up guiding the crew to various locations and realized that being a wildlife cameraman combined his interests in travel, adventure, and underwater exploration.

Allan has become a leading cameraman and has contributed to many important wildlife TV series. He started his career at a time when few people had explored Antarctica. While others focused on filming coral reefs, elephants, or chimpanzees, he became known as the "cold man," capturing stunning footage that was waiting to be filmed.

When he began his career 35 years ago, the camera and communication technology were very basic. He notes that filming is much easier now. In the past, if you recorded something, you had to remember it because film was expensive. Today, with digital technology, you can shoot many scenes and review them immediately, which allows for more flexibility.

Allan believes his experience in cold environments is valuable. He feels comfortable on sea ice, which has become second nature to him. Although he sometimes gets cold toes, he finds the polar regions to be healthy places without leeches, diseases, or mosquitoes.

Wildlife filming has its successes, but also its challenges and awkward moments. For example, while filming kittiwakes in the Orkneys, he struggled to identify the birds. Recently, he received permission to film in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, which is known for its polar bears and is difficult to access. In April, temperatures can drop to -32°C, and the strong winds make carrying cameras through deep snow very challenging. After walking for five hours a day and observing polar bear dens for 23 days, he had only seen one mother bear and her cub.

On the 24th day, he felt fully immersed in the polar bear environment. He describes how he and his team would wait patiently, moving around to stay warm. After hours of watching, he finally caught a brief glimpse of a bear. The camera was focused, and he quickly adjusted to capture the moment. He watched as the bear emerged from the den, followed by her two cubs, who were seeing the world for the first time. It was an exciting moment for Allan, who felt like he had front-row seats to a remarkable show.

Now, Allan hopes to create his own documentary about climate change in the Arctic, featuring the stories of the people who live there and witness its effects firsthand. He believes this could lead to an extraordinary film.

In 2004, Pen Hadow became the first person to walk alone to the North Pole without getting supplies along the way. This journey involved swimming in extremely cold waters and facing dangers like frostbite and polar bears. Just eight months later, he reached the South Pole as well. Now, he is back in the Arctic, preparing for an even more ambitious expedition. Explorers like Pen are confident and determined individuals, and this time, there is a lot at stake. Pen and two colleagues will embark on a three-month, 1,000-kilometre trek to the North Pole, where they will measure the thickness and density of the ice. No one has done this before, and Pen understands that the results will be crucial for scientists. This research will provide a clearer understanding of how global warming is affecting the polar ice.

Pen was prepared for this kind of work from a young age. He was raised by his father's old nanny, who had worked for the famous polar explorer, Scott of the Antarctic. She toughened him up by sending him out into harsh weather with minimal clothing. His father also inspired his love for adventure in cold places, and Pen developed remarkable physical endurance. He is married to Mary, a horsewoman who shares his passion for the outdoors. Mary helps run his polar guide business and worries more about him when he is at home than when he is on an expedition. She once raced against him in a mountain event, finishing an hour ahead of him. They live in the countryside with their two children.

Pen admits that it is harder to be away from his family this time. When he last went on an expedition, his children were very young, and he made a mistake in how he said goodbye. He told his son to take care of his mother and sister, which put too much pressure on the boy. This time, Pen plans to have little contact with his family while in the Arctic, as he believes that calling them would remind them of how far away he is. In the days leading up to his departure, he is carefully preparing his equipment. He knows that once he is on the ice, it will be difficult to fix anything or do anything complicated.

Joining him on this expedition will be Ann Daniels, a leading polar explorer, and Martin Hartley, the expedition photographer. They will have a support crew of six people who will fly in supplies. Pen finds being part of a team stressful, and he is also concerned about his age. He will turn 47 soon and feels he has not trained as much as he would like. He often finds that organizational tasks take priority over training, which makes him anxious about the challenges ahead.

Pen believes that this mission connects exploration with the pursuit of knowledge that motivated earlier explorers. He acknowledges that reaching the North Pole was a personal goal, but this time, the data they collect will benefit scientists and help raise awareness about what is happening in the Arctic Ocean. He feels that their unique skills, which may seem unusual in everyday life, are now very important and relevant. "Suddenly, we’re socially useful again," he says.

Text: 'I took a year off. What was I going to do? Being a successful Olympian is a wonderful experience. I had the opportunity to do more writing, TV work, and speak to businesses and schools. While I enjoyed these activities, I felt there was nothing competitive to focus on. I wanted to stay fit in case I decided to compete for another Olympic spot. So, I signed up for marathons and triathlons. That should have been enough, but I kept thinking about Ben Fogle’s invitation: ‘Do you want to row across the Atlantic with me?’ I have always loved rowing and the feeling of the boat moving through the water. I missed that, but I wasn’t ready to train every day. Still, I wanted some kind of competition. I asked some rowing friends if they wanted to join the race, but they weren’t very interested. I knew that if I entered the race, even though it was called an adventure, I would want to win. Would rowing with Ben give me the best chance to win? Probably not. But being an underdog without pressure was appealing. I contacted Ben, who was already planning to enter the race and had managed to gather the large entry fee and deposit for a boat. This made the race feel more real. We discussed the costs; the boat and equipment would cost £70,000, which was a lot of money. We believed we had a good chance, but it would still require effort to secure funding. Additionally, I had to consider the loss of income from being away from home. Speaking at business conferences is one of the best ways to earn money as a retired athlete. It’s nice that people are interested, but I find it hard to talk about my past achievements without a new goal. Joining the race would mean I wouldn’t just be discussing my past; I would be actively doing something again: rowing across the Atlantic. I learned a lot while planning this adventure, but one of the biggest lessons was to appreciate the simpler life of a full-time athlete. My Olympic training was tough, but it was straightforward. I trained almost every day, but my schedule was set, and I had support from doctors and dieticians. I was initially worried about how people would view me racing with a TV presenter. I feared it would seem like I just wanted to be on TV, rather than choosing a better partner to win. However, my concerns faded as we prepared. The Atlantic Rowing Race is about more than just rowing; it’s also a mental challenge. Ben had completed the difficult Marathon des Sables, spent time at sea, and lived on a deserted island. However, he struggled with rowing. I was surprised by how little natural ability he had, and he was shocked by my lack of understanding. I could have been more patient, but I felt it was important to be honest with Ben about the significant improvements he needed to make. I should have realized that this would be his level when I agreed to race with him.'

Just over a year ago, I left my job in London to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless and dreamed of cold, empty landscapes, perhaps because I was tired of the noise and crowds of the city. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They offered me a position as a husky dog handler for the busy winter season. From December to February, they take many tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the snow and ice, for trips ranging from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but now have over 100. Recently, they acquired a second location called the 'wilderness farm,' which they described as a beautiful but basic place with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join their team for three months, but warned me that the hours would be long, the conditions tough, and the work very physical. I began packing right away.

On November 6, while flying to Finland, I found myself staring at a page with over 100 pictures of huskies. I was supposed to memorize their names, but I felt distracted and anxious. Instead, I looked out the window. I remembered that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. However, I felt like I was witnessing winter moving south, as rivers were freezing over.

On November 7, I took a bus north, which was everything I had hoped for. We drove through endless dark forests filled with snow-covered trees, stopping occasionally for reindeer. I arrived at the farm after dark and was immediately given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. Anna asked if I wanted to be thrown in at the deep end, which was not really a question. I followed the sound of barking and reached the dogsheds, where three people were busy harnessing the excited huskies to sleds. I could barely introduce myself because everyone was too busy to talk. I stood aside and petted one of the calmer dogs. Someone urged me to get in the sled, and I almost fell in. A command was shouted, and we took off into the dark, guided only by a headlamp.

By November 15, I was quickly learning how to be a husky guide, but first, I faced a tough questioning about my skills. Anna asked if I was useful, and I was unsure. Further questions revealed that I had never driven a snowmobile, done woodwork, or used an axe. Finally, someone asked if I had a driving license, and I nodded, feeling relieved. 

I learned the basics of dog-sledding quickly: lean into the corners, use both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. However, many other tasks were complicated. Simple things like feeding and watering the dogs became challenging in freezing temperatures. A bowl of water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a 'soup' of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, I was overwhelmed with instructions, and my muscles ached from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled around by excited huskies. But I felt proud. I emailed my friends, saying, "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw—in the snow!"

On that day, as Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters gathered to understand her amazing performance. They noted that her time was fast enough to qualify for the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a natural remedy, emu oil, which Olympic gold medallist Cathy Freeman had suggested to help heal Radcliffe's injuries from an accident when she collided with a bike during training. Radcliffe said that the achievement didn’t fully register with her at the time. Looking back, she realizes it was a significant moment, but she felt it was just part of her plan for that day, so it didn’t feel overwhelming. She and her team had decided not to set any limits on their performance, following the motto: no limits.

During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent expressed concern about her pace, fearing it might cause her to drop out. Hartmann was frustrated by this worry, although he acknowledged that anyone unfamiliar with her fitness might see it as a risk to start so quickly. With 800 meters left, Radcliffe began to calculate her finish time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she crossed the line in less than three minutes. After running 41 kilometers at a fast pace, she managed to sprint the last stretch in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." She remembered the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never expected anyone to come close to that time for a long time, and she thought, "I will come back and do it next year." Unfortunately, that did not happen.

After the race, everyone was curious about how Radcliffe, who had an unusual running style, had outperformed the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had spent weeks with Radcliffe, providing daily training sessions to support her as she covered 250-300 kilometers each week. He said, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medallists, and no one could handle that level of pain like her. She would push me to my limits; I had to ice my thumbs afterward because I was in so much pain." Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no time for pleasantries; she was ready for a two-hour training session. "Paula would push you to give everything you had. That's what made her exceptional." 

During this time, Hartmann dedicated so much to Radcliffe that his other athletes became resentful. When asked if she knew why no one has come close to her record, Radcliffe replied, "Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany (a two-time London marathon winner) might break through. Maybe it's because people are competing against each other instead of focusing on their own performance." She explained, "That mindset of never easing up, even when you’re winning, probably helped me because I never thought, 'I can relax now.' It was always about pushing as hard as I could." Radcliffe did not realize at the time that this marathon was the peak of her career, and she would never run that fast again. However, she inspired many women to take up long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. At that time, there was a lot of discussion about a food ‘revolution’ happening in Britain. I believed we had created a series that truly contributed to this movement, but I still worried: would people enjoy a cooking show that included not just techniques but also history, nostalgia, and science? I watched the first episode feeling both excited and anxious. Fortunately, I didn’t need to worry. The show became very successful, leading to many other interesting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant. Each project felt like a journey, whether into the past, the mind, or cooking techniques. I later wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving passports, suitcases, and travel plans. The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who has dedicated his life to making the best golden pasta. These artisans have spent years chasing their own ideas of perfection. 

Perfection is very personal. Even the simple task of choosing which dishes to feature in the series was challenging, and I knew I would disappoint some people by not including their favorites. I could imagine them asking, “Where’s steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?” However, after a long meeting with the TV production team, we finally created a list that would satisfy everyone. This experience reinforced my belief that each person has their own view of perfection, shaped by their emotions, memories, and environment. Despite the book’s title, I knew I wouldn’t claim that the recipes were the ultimate versions. I believed that by using my skills and knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. 

The dictionary defines ‘perfection’ as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. It’s about trying ideas and refining them until something unique emerges. The TV series allowed me to explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen in restaurants before. I was excited to delve into memory and nostalgia in food because I started my career in a similar way. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. I had many adventures, such as visiting a canning factory that was processing the wrong type of tomato and going to a dairy farm that was so far from perfect that we had to stop filming there! While perfecting each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow, using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital scanning machine, and almost burning my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a real Neapolitan-style pizza.

We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van suddenly made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the hood. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets, looking like he knew what he was doing. Finally, he said, “Actually, I have no idea what I’m doing,” and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried and said, “We can’t stay here forever.” The field was empty, just grass and many flowers like poppies and daisies. I agreed with Bea, saying, “No, we can’t stay here forever.” We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass and said, “Tell us a story.” Bea lay down next to her and encouraged me to tell a story. So, I shared a story about how, the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I described their conversation about breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. Bea said, “That’s silly, no one understands bird language.” My eyes felt teary. I replied, “I do,” but I didn’t sound very sure. Bea called me a liar, and I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? I started to doubt myself and turned to Mum for help, but she had fallen asleep in the sun. 

John returned with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van to a nearby hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out, but the boys waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café that was a little away from the road. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “It might be expensive.” Mum reassured him, saying, “We’ll just have some tea,” and we sat down in the shade. The tea was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot and said, “It’s like syrup in there.” We stayed at the café all day while John looked at the engine with a worried expression. When it started to get dark, he said, “I guess it’s a miracle we made it this far.” 

Mum took out blankets and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on solid ground. John said, “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech.” Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind us with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept thinking about how we would get home since our van had to be towed. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then, I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in the hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. Unlike her, they were not competing. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city named Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke good English. They discussed the music they were playing, their recent travels, and their future plans. 

“I think I’m doing Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy mentioned, trying to sound impressive. However, she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world, making her miss so much school that she was no longer officially enrolled. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 

Lucy hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which selected only fifteen pianists her age from thousands of applicants. She had made it in, and her dad celebrated by buying her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant. Her little brother Gus dreamed of being at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t applied herself; her mother had filled out the application and sent in a CD. “I didn’t want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought her mom just didn’t want to give her the chance to say no. Back then, she believed that causing trouble was the worst thing to do, so she didn’t think about trying to back out.

The guy from Tokyo leaned in, seeming surprised. “Tanglewood?” he asked. “Yeah.” “How old are you?” “Fifteen.” He exchanged a look with Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy hadn’t meant to brag; it was hard to know when sharing her achievements was just fitting in or showing off. “It’s just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they’re trying…” Liesel/Louisa then looked across the room, as if she saw someone she needed to talk to, and left. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, shaggy hair, like many musicians, showing they were both music lovers and a bit rebellious. “Once, when I was about eight,” Lucy replied. He started to respond when Lucy's grandfather appeared beside her. 

“Lucy, let me introduce you to someone,” he said, pulling her away from the conversation. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” “They’re not the competition,” Lucy replied. “Everyone is the competition,” her grandfather insisted. He took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of what was said. 

Later, in the elevator to their suite, her grandfather said, “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” She liked that. Being recognized felt good, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention she received. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her respect from her school friends. Even her best friend, Reyna, wouldn’t care that she could play a difficult Rachmaninov piece perfectly. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered.

Text: "‘Spending too much time online isn’t good for you. You should spend more time in the real world,’ said my dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I decided to look into what experts say about this topic, and I found it quite interesting. Research shows that many teenagers who use social media have a large group of real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are developing important technical skills needed in today’s digital world. 

Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, explains that ‘social networking is now a key part of growing up. Teenagers don’t just use media casually like adults do; they live in it. This isn’t necessarily good or bad – it depends on how you use it.’ 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, describes it as ‘the modern version of hanging out at a youth club, where parents used to share jokes and gossip. It serves a similar purpose: helping teenagers form their identity away from their parents and learn to handle teenage issues while connecting with their peers.’ 

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson states, ‘Adolescence is a time for self-discovery. Social networking can help you figure out who you are: you can share your favorite music or sports, find out what you enjoy, and see that others have different perspectives. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media.’ He adds that social media can be helpful for shy individuals: ‘Communicating online can feel easier than in person, and it allows you to practice social skills in a less intimidating setting.’ 

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can be beneficial for quiet individuals with specific interests because they connect with others who share those interests. ‘If you’re one of only a few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But finding a social networking group of similar people can change that, making you feel more connected and popular in a different way,’ he says. 

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared an interesting point: ‘Young people who discover new interests online, join networks of like-minded individuals, and create their own content are truly making the most of social networks.’ She believes social networking is becoming a creative outlet: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about their interests. Photo-sharing sites are also enhancing creativity, allowing photographers to connect, learn, share images, and deepen their skills. ‘This all improves employability and will be beneficial in the workplace,’ she says. 

‘Every business uses social media to promote and build brand awareness – understanding how it works is essential. For instance, if you create a product and have 1,000 friends on various social networks, they could all be potential customers. Linking these networks can create your customer base.’ 

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they enter the workforce, Matthews agrees. ‘One great feature of many sites is the chance to collaborate with others to create and share content. Collaboration is a vital skill in the 21st century and is important for being employable in a digital world.’"

When people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. However, my parents were not looking for a quiet getaway when they planned our summer vacation this year. My dad seemed determined to create what he thought was the ultimate family bonding experience, which my twin brother and I found terrifying. “Not enough people do this anymore,” my parents kept saying, while we exchanged worried looks.

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and a mix of clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. Still, I had some strategies to cope. With barely enough space left for us, we began “The Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our spacious home for smaller accommodations over the next five thousand miles made me wonder what we had gotten ourselves into.

We headed west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the highway by a dust storm. We quickly learned that cattle have the right-of-way on the road!

The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. The desert turned into mountains, and the days started to blend together, but each experience was still unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then moved on to Pagosa Springs, Colorado, where the strong smell of sulfur hinted at what was to come. As we climbed to our next stop, we realized that the roads marked for Jeeps were best suited for actual Jeep drivers.

Every place we visited showed a mix of old and new. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. Disappointment turned to laughter when we saw the huge “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. We passed many wind farms on our way to Yellowstone National Park, where we watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. “Bear jams,” where traffic would stop to let bears cross, were common, and our close encounter with a bear (and a nervous park ranger) gave us unforgettable memories.

As we drove, life back home faded away. Even the hotel we stayed in, which was an old building with no internet or cell phone service, couldn’t dampen our excitement. In exchange for these inconveniences, I experienced some of the most beautiful views I’ve ever seen. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, we began our journey back south. My parents were right: you don’t need to travel to a faraway place to find something amazing. 

Returning home was a mix of emotions, but at least I hadn’t argued with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our adventure to look through, and I knew that the memories I would cherish most were the unexpected and spontaneous moments.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy, because her family was separating for two years. Rose’s father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Meanwhile, Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy needed to finish her last year of school, so it was better for her to remain at the college where she had the best room, complete with a kitchen and study area. She also had free access to the Internet and phone. Jeff and Dahlia would keep an eye on Amy, whether she liked it or not.

Rose, on the other hand, was moving in with her grandmother. She only had vague memories of Daisy from past holidays and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not very excited, but Daisy was happy to have Rose with her. There had been some disagreement between Rose’s parents and her grandmother in the past, which meant Rose had spent summers away from Daisy. The last time Rose saw her grandmother, she was only ten, but she remembered those times fondly. Dahlia had mentioned that living with Daisy would be interesting because Daisy was very social and loved to bring people together. Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon, which made her smile. Daisy was not a typical frail old lady; she seemed to attend more social events than anyone else.

Before the move, Dahlia and Rose had a serious talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She understood the importance of healthy eating, fitness, and sleep. However, she wanted one thing: her independence. Living with Daisy would meet her needs, but Rose wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, and go out without always asking for permission. She believed she could be trusted to handle these small things. She didn’t want to be nagged about homework or curfews, and she didn’t want to be dragged around by her grandmother. Daisy understood this.

Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies only, which made Rose very happy. They all agreed that their relationship would be based on trust. Daisy would trust Rose to make mature decisions, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too controlling. If either of them crossed a line, they would talk about it.

Rose was not a wild child; her few friends were similar, so her school reports were always good. In five weeks, she would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin a new chapter in her life. This would be her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this would be the last time, as she would be starting her final two years of school. For Rose, this was a new moment in her life, a new piece in the puzzle that was her journey.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first to suggest she might write a novel. She thought writing a book would be a great achievement because it seemed challenging, and she wasn’t aware of what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When she turned 13, she decided to give it a try. Now, the novel she started at that age is about to be published. Recently, she told her former teacher about it, and the teacher was surprised. She had expected Charlotte to write a book when she was 30 or 40, but Charlotte didn’t understand why she should wait to pursue something she was good at.

On a winter afternoon, I met Charlotte in her publisher's office. I knew I was interviewing a 15-year-old about her book, but I was still surprised to see a teenager there. The book is a significant achievement; it has a strong and exciting story. The only thing that reveals its young author is the age of the main character. A public relations representative is present in case Charlotte needs support, but she doesn’t. She is confident, intelligent, and steady, showing no signs of overconfidence.

Charlotte is aware of the limitations of her youth. When I ask her about the complex moral issues in her book, she says, “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers.” She believes her age doesn’t limit her understanding of the world, but she doesn’t consider herself particularly wise. She is interested in the theme of taking responsibility.

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are often misrepresented in fiction. She identifies three common types of teenage characters: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the socially awkward teen. She finds it frustrating that there aren’t many stories about teenagers who are just fine. She feels that some writers unintentionally suggest that teenagers don’t know who they are because they lack experience, which can harm their self-confidence.

Charlotte enjoys reading works by famous fantasy authors, but these books almost discouraged her from writing. She wondered if she needed to explore deep psychological themes to write well. However, she appreciates a book called How Not to Write a Novel, which advises that if readers can guess what will happen next, the suspense is likely gone.

Some might argue that Charlotte’s parents, both journalists, played a crucial role in getting her novel published. Her father’s connection in publishing helped her book get read initially. She recognizes her good luck, as it is challenging for any new writer to have their first novel read. “Every aspiring writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, it’s up to you. Ultimately, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte concludes.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping and wanted to show off, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He approached the ramp quickly and flew into the air, arms waving. Even we could see something was off. We held our breath. He landed hard, losing both skis, and flipped head-first into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth kindly reminded us, ‘speed can be unpredictable.’ Maybe freestyle skiing wasn’t for me. On past ski trips, I enjoyed practicing turns in the snow, but I wasn’t one of those teenagers who did tricks in skate parks. I thought it looked fun, but I worried that if I tried to join them, I would be laughed at. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. It had a large indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow, where students practiced their tricks and landed in foam pits – not exactly a realistic start for what awaited us on the slopes. After practicing indoors, students went outside to try their skills for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan cheerfully promised. ‘Before places like this, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,’ Gareth explained. ‘But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope steepens for landing. If you land in the right zone, you keep moving forward, which reduces the impact. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which hurts. So, speed is important. At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore my brain’s fears and go straight towards the jump. My legs seemed to want to go backward as I neared the launch point, so I ended up landing on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday, I felt exhausted. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ Gareth advised. 

On the second day, we started on the trampolines. I thought I would dislike being indoors while looking at the snowy mountains, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some exercises mimicked ski-jumping moves, while others taught us ‘aerial awareness’ – understanding what your body is doing while spinning in the air. Gareth provided a running commentary. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement – every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off and then found myself lying in the foam cubes next to the trampoline. We returned to the mountain to try again. There were more challenges before I finally landed correctly. Gareth seemed as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of achieving such a difficult goal. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I forced myself to keep my speed up as I approached the jump, took off, and landed correctly. Then I noticed both skis sliding down the slope ahead, no longer attached to my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty from fear, and you grip the harness tightly. Suddenly, the ride stops, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs upwards. There’s a pause, then a sudden drop that makes your stomach feel weightless. You rush forward, turn sharply to the left, and go upside down. Your senses are overwhelmed, and you scream in fear. But you chose to be here, just like millions of others who pay to enter theme parks.

What surprises me is how amusement parks, with their thrilling rides, have become a massive industry. To create the excitement and escape from reality that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers, designers, and marketing professionals working behind the scenes. The idea of being a "rollercoaster designer" might sound like a childhood dream, but it is actually a complex job. Designers must find the right mix of fun and fear while keeping riders safe, and they need to introduce new elements to keep people coming back.

While many think rollercoasters have become more extreme, most of the techniques used today, like the wheels that allow rides to go upside down, were developed by American designer John Miller in the early 20th century. During his time, there were fewer safety regulations, and some rides were quite uncomfortable for passengers. Now, designers must work within the limits set by specialized ride manufacturers.

I spoke with three experts in rollercoaster design. Professor Brendan Walker, a "thrill engineer" with a background in aeronautics, explained that the skill lies in putting all the elements together. Dr. John Roberts, a fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering, added that it’s about quickly alternating between feelings of excitement and safety, so riders feel thrilled but not unsafe. 

To create an outstanding ride, teams must develop a strong story, whether it’s a space adventure or a jungle chase, that complements any new features like the tallest drops or most twists. However, Professor Walker noted that, like in many creative fields, intuition, experience, and trial-and-error are crucial. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that it helps to be passionate about thrills to understand what riders want and to test rides before they open to the public.

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers would need to adopt new technologies like virtual reality. Walker responded that while virtual reality can enhance the experience, it is not a replacement for the physical thrill of the ride. He believes that the core experience of rollercoasters will remain the most important aspect for many years to come.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already accomplished a lot as a choreographer, creating performances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally, which makes me wonder why she fits both roles into her busy life. She explains, “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the instructions of demanding choreographers. It can be tense and frustrating. Choreographers sometimes forget how it feels to rehearse all day.”

As a choreographer, she takes on a teaching role and enjoys working with young dancers. “Beginners are often open to trying new ideas. In some ways, it’s easier to work with them than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They are eager to succeed but don’t yet fully understand their strengths and weaknesses. This lack of clarity helps them accept even tough criticism. However, they might still question my advice, and I appreciate their honest feedback.”

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, letting the music guide her. “There might be music I don’t like, but I still strive to create the best dance routine for it. If the dancers don’t connect with a certain piece, it can be frustrating, but I must find solutions. I can’t just choose a new piece of music. Ideally, I would like to experiment more and switch to different pieces, which would help improve the atmosphere during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I often work on large productions where the music is already decided and cannot be changed.”

Miranda believes in building connections with new people rather than sticking to one institution. “It’s important to meet new people, but I have to remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I need to adapt my approach each time I work somewhere new, which helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.”

We discuss a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. “There have been glamorous documentaries in the past that were misleading,” Miranda says. “This one tries to show the real life inside a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer receives endless corrections, and I smiled because I recognized that struggle. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch, but it’s genuine. The public often underestimates the hard work and dedication required in ballet.”

I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. “It’s when everything the company has put together – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. While perfection is hard to achieve, aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can help you overlook some artistic mistakes. I’ve been part of productions where the dance steps were excellent, but distracting costumes or props were disappointing.”

Given her diverse work, I wonder how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? “People like to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s a trend to focus on becoming an expert in a narrow field, but I don’t follow that. Maybe one day I’ll be known for one thing, but for now, I want to broaden my horizons.”

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can watch everything on television. I agreed that TV shows amazing things, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation inspired my unusual four-day trip and a film that encourages people to turn off their TVs. A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main focus of my film. I added three wheels and some cables to it, attaching them to old seatbelts over my shoulders. I placed my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, even spending one night on the beach. Several friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and motivating me to keep going. I have done many walking trips in recent years, but this was completely different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads, which allowed me to stop at roadside cafés and enjoy a cappuccino on the sofa instead of having my sandwiches blown away while sitting on a rock. I often had to tell people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to share how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I usually travel with, was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be a good idea. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket, as the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still seemed confused, he smiled and showed me on board.

Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to talk before our first swim. Our guides explained that a support boat would follow us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first proper swim of 1.5 km. I felt nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves became bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. However, I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own.

The following days had a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the scenery. As the swims became longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. I felt less need for the support boat. I can hardly wait to come back again next year.
