Being a flight attendant is not an easy job, but it has many rewards. Since I started, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting, which makes it a great job for someone young like me!

As a child, I attended a boarding school far from my family, so I often flew alone at the beginning and end of each term. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I would ask the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed with me and inspired me to leave my banking job and find a new career.

During the interview for this job, I met many other young people, many of whom were also changing careers. They were often very qualified, just like me. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I wanted to stand out, so instead of just saying I loved to travel, I talked about my skills and past work experience. This approach helped me get the job!

I would recommend this job to anyone because it has many benefits, although the free flights are not the main reason. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: "no one’s finished until everyone’s finished." It feels like a big family; even if we don’t see each other often, we are still close. When I’m off duty, I don’t have to take work home with me. If I do encounter difficult passengers, which is rare, I remind myself that the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!

At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy watching the children achieve things they never thought they could. Most of them already know how to swim and play table tennis, but rock climbing is a new challenge for many. Some kids feel nervous at first, but with a little encouragement, they decide to try, and eventually, they all reach the top. This accomplishment makes them feel fantastic.

At the start of the week, some children miss their homes. Interestingly, it’s not the younger ones who struggle the most; it’s usually those aged ten to thirteen. We limit their mobile phone use. We tell them they can call home after lunch, but when they ask again later, we say it’s too late and suggest they call tomorrow. Most children adjust within a couple of days, and by the end of the week, they come to thank us for a wonderful time.

Sometimes, it’s not just the children who feel lonely. We also have parents who frequently call to check on their kids, which is often unnecessary. Their children are usually busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to ask the parents to call back later.

We often see a specific type of child at camp, usually dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into more appropriate attire, but soon they understand why it’s important.

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be skilled musicians. It opened in London last year after five successful years in the USA, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, putting on the show with an all-British cast was not easy. The UK has stricter rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can perform more often. As a result, the production needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors based in the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

Even though the London theatre is larger than the one in the USA, it has been full every night, with audiences eager to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He shared how busy the young actors are, mentioning, ‘We have regular school lessons at the theatre. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ 

I asked Jamie what his classmates thought of the show. He replied, ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, which made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them.’ When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to join him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was relieved that the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes!

Although the young actors were already musicians, with some playing multiple instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie admitted that the challenging part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
